DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Photographers, Reporter Injured in Melee at Club
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-16, bgnning ``2 Live...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with protest at Austin concert; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A dispute with promoters prompted the rap group 2 Live Crew to cancel a concert, triggering a melee by unruly fans that injured two newspaper photographers and a reporter. The rappers, whose album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has been ruled obscene by a Florida judge and banned in San Antonio, refused to play Saturday night at the Longhorn Ballroom after a promoter refused to pay them in advance. Shortly afterward, about 50 people went on a rampage, breaking chairs and throwing bottles. Security guards forced the protesters outside, but several windows in the front of the building were broken and some cars were vandalized before about 50 police in riot gear arrived and dispersed the crowd, witnesses said. The ruckus lasted about 12 minutes. Dallas Times Herald photographers Jesse Hornbuckle and Cedric Thompson, assigned to cover the concert, were treated for minor injuries at Methodist Medical Center in Dallas early Sunday. Reporter Mindy Donnelly was hit in the head and lost a tooth cap but didn't require treatment. Hornbuckle said up to 10 fans attacked him as he attempted to photograph a smaller group attacking Thompson. Cameras and other equipment belonging to both photographers were destroyed by the fans. Hornbuckle salvaged one roll of film, and his picture of a fan being restrained by guards appeared in one edition of Sunday's Times Herald. A car belonging to another Herald reporter was vandalized. The fans also smashed the windshield of a KXAS-TV remote broadcast van. Bob Lowder, a spokesman at the Longhorn, referred all inquiries about the payment dispute and possible refunds to the show's promoters. They promoters did not return telephone calls Sunday. Lowder said a damage estimate wasn't immediately available. But he said crews had cleaned up most of the mess in time for an AIDS benefit at the club Sunday afternoon. 2 Live Crew performed Sunday night at the Club XS in Austin, with a ``clean'' concert at 7 p.m., and an unexpurgated show set for 11 p.m. for fans age 21 and over. The 860-seat club was sold out for the late show, said promoter Jerry Latouf. About 10 picketers from the American Family Association gathered in front of the Austin club. They carried placards denouncing the group's explicit lyrics. The group held up signs reading ``2 Lewd Crew'' and ``Women Are Not Sexual Toys.'' They also chanted ``2 Live Crew, Too obscene.'' Band leader Luther Campbell asked the mostly male crowd of about 150 people if they had seen the protesters outside and then read off an obscene message he asked the crowd to deliver them on their way out. Latouf said the group was paid in full before the first show. ``That's standard operating procedure in the entertainment business,'' Latouf said. ``You pay the group half of their money when you book them and the other half 10 minutes before they go on stage. ``I can't imagine not paying a band before they go on,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: No Serious Injuries in Emergency Landing of United Airlines Flight
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines flight with 83 people on board made an emergency landing Sunday after the plane lost cabin pressure en route from Chicago to Spokane, Wash., officials said. There were no serious injuries, but 16 people were taken to two hospitals for treatment of earaches and nausea. All were treated and released. The traffic control tower at Billings Logan International Airport said it received the pilot's call for medical help just before 2:30 p.m. and sent out a request for all available assistance. A dozen fire trucks and ambulances were on hand when the Boeing 737-300 made a safe landing and taxied to a stop just east of the terminal. United Flight 793 had 78 passengers, three flight attendants, a pilot and co-pilot, said Ray Anderson, the airline's Billings manager. The plane was at an altitude of about 37,000 feet and flying over Miles City, 146 miles east of Billings, when lost some if its pressure, said Tom Binford, assistant director of aviation here. Anderson said pressure stabilized on the plane when it reached an altitude of 19,000 feet. It already had been a bumpy flight from Chicago, said passenger Mary Burnham of Newtown, Conn., who was flying with her husband and two children to visit friends in Missoula. ``Everybody knew something was wrong,'' Burnham said after the landing. ``You could feel it in your ears. They wanted to land in Miles City, but there wasn't enough runway.''

DOC.HEAD: French Troops To Stay In Germany At Least Four More Years
DOC.TEXT: France plans to keep troops in Germany for at least four more years and is intent on remaining Western Europe's top military power, the country's defense minister says. The Cabinet minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, speaking on a radio show Sunday, rejected any suggestion French troops withdraw from Germany by the end of the year. ``That won't happen for at least four or five years,'' he said, adding that withdrawal even then would depend on actions of the Soviet Union and coordination with Western allies. Chevenement said the eventual withdrawal of the 50,000-strong unit called French Forces in Germany would fit in with plans to reduce France's armed forces by 35,000 men. The defense minister stressed that these tentative withdrawal plans have no bearing on French troops in Berlin, whose status is governed by a Four Powers agreement, nor on a newly formed joint French-German brigade. Chevenement recalled that France refused to endorse a declaration at last week's NATO summit stipulating that the alliance would use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. ``It was in our interests to refuse to go along with this idea that one uses nuclear weapons as a last resort, when all would be lost,'' he said. France would stick with its ``completely opposite'' strategy of nuclear deterrence, he said. ``This is extremely important for France and for Europe.'' France ``is the biggest military power in Europe'' after the Soviet Union, Chevenement said, and must maintain all its capabilities. ``In five years, there will be a strategic void, which is very dangerous because a void of arms can lead to outside interference.''

DOC.HEAD: Victims Of Nuclear Accident In Cuba for Treatment
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 Soviet children with health problems caused by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant explosion are in Cuba for medical treatment at a specially designed center, the country's news agency says. The group of 300 children that arrived Sunday was the fourth to come to Havana this month for treatment of illnesses related to the Ukrainian power plant disaster, Prensa Latina said in a dispatch. The agency said Cuban President Fidel Castro had welcomed a group of 255 who arrived on July 2. It said about 1,000 children from the Chernobyl area are being treated in a specially designed medical center. ``We have all the conditions to do it and we are doing it very gladly,'' Castro told reporters, according to the news agency. The medical center, called Pioneer City, is located east of Havana on the oceanfront. The complex includes 520 houses, two hospitals, 15 dining halls, amusement parks, video and movie houses, the agency said. At least 31 deaths are officially blamed on the April 26, 1986, explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant. The actual toll is much higher and includes people stricken with radiation-related diseases.

DOC.HEAD: Human Growth Hormone Researcher Tells of Inspiration
DOC.TEXT: Watching his parents grow old in a nursing home helped motivate Dr. Daniel Rudman to seek out a new use for a hormone therapy his research team found can reverse some of the damage of aging. Researchers at veterans' hospitals in Milwaukee and Chicago, led by the 62-year-old endocrinologist, found that injections of human growth hormone, a once-rare protein made through genetic engineering, will help old people build up sagging muscles, take off flab and grow more youthful-looking skin. Their findings were published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine. While his work in the field of hormone therapy has drawn attention in the past, ``I'll tell you, this is the one that's brought the most interest,'' Rudman said. ``This type of work really touches a nerve center.'' Rudman was among a group of physicians in the 1960s and 1970s who used human growth hormone taken from pituitary glands in cadavers to treat children whose growth is retarded because they don't make enough of the protein. The results ``were truly remarkable,'' Rudman said. The children not only grew quickly but also lost fat and rapidly grew lean muscle, he said. During that period, Rudman visited his parents in nursing homes and was shocked by the poor medical care given to the residents. ``It was obvious to me that medical conditions in nursing homes were primitive compared to the kind of medicine that younger people get,'' he said. On a hunch, Rudman said he decided to use the same blood test he was using for children to check for levels of human growth hormone in the elderly. He interested other endocrinologists in his idea of testing the effect of human growth hormone on the elderly and began some limited testing in 1980, he said. Rudman began a pilot study at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in North Chicago, Ill., and continued it when he moved to the Clement J. Zablocki VA Medical Center in Milwaukee and the Medical College of Wisconsin in 1988. All of the 12 healthy men ages 61 to 81 who had deficient levels of growth hormone and were given additional amounts of the hormone for six months showed significant physical improvements, Rudman said. Their muscle mass grew, their skin became thicker and more youthlike, and their fat mass shrunk, removing the effects of an estimated 20 years of aging. However, Rudman cautions that the treatment is not the fountain of youth, and should not be used routinely until questions are answered about its long-term effects and possible hazards.

DOC.HEAD: Many of California's Non-Voters Tell Pollsters They're Just Too Busy
DOC.TEXT: Most people in California are too busy doing other things to bother voting in elections, according to a newspaper survey. Too much to do was the most frequent response given by 2,260 people polled by telephone for the survey, which was conducted by the Los Angeles Times. The poll's margin of error was 3 percent. About 35 percent of those who were registered to vote but did not said they were too busy, the newspaper reported Sunday. A lack of interest in politics, the next most common reason, was cited by 8 percent. In last month's state primaries, about 14 million who were eligible to vote failed to do so. About 4.9 million people did vote. Non-voters, whether registered or not, share many qualities with those who do vote, having the same range of views on abortion, capital punishment and taxes, the newspaper reported. They also were split evenly between support of Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic candidate for governor, and Republican candidate Pete Wilson. Where they seem to differ is how they perceive voting. For the non-voters, the practice is seen as more trouble than it's worth, pollsters said. Among unregistered non-voters, 22 percent said they were too busy and 21 percent said they did not care. Other reasons given by both groups were dislike of the candidates and the feeling that voting doesn't matter. Most non-voters are young, with 56 percent under age 40, the poll showed.

DOC.HEAD: President Gets Public Support for War on Tamil Rebels
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: President Ranasinghe Premadasa has switched from negotiating to fighting in the 7-year-old Tamil rebellion and has gained broad public support. Thousands of people send money to a fund for soldiers' families each day and young men stand in line to join in the army. The main opposition party, which called Premadasa's conciliation a joke, has expressed support for the new policy. After three weeks of fierce fighting, however, advancing government troops are bogged down by land mines and booby traps in the east and are pushed to the wall in the north. At least 2,109 combatants have died in the new battle for control of the north and the east, where guerrillas of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam militia want a separate nation they would call Eelam. It began June 11 and ended a 13-month truce during which Premadasa tried to talk the Tigers into laying down their arms in exchange for limited autonomy. The cease-fire had been tenuous, and the Tigers began accusing the government early in June of trying to wreck negotiations. On June 11, they overran dozens of police stations in the east and captured 850 policemen. The military says the Tigers killed at least 330 of the officers; the rest are also feared dead. Premadasa's government established a fund to help families of the policemen and other members of the security forces who have been killed. Sri Lankans have contributed 40 million rupees ($1.05 million) to the fund and other donations have been received from Sri Lankans in the United States, Japan and Britain, the Defense Ministry said. No breakdown is available, but most of the money is thought to come from the ethnic Sinhalese majority that has dominated Sri Lanka since the island republic, then called Ceylon, became independent of Britain in 1948. At military headquarters in Colombo, thousands of young men have been lining up to join the army. Defense Minister Cyril Ranatunge said 30,000 volunteered after newspaper advertisements appeared two weeks ago. ``We must finish this Tamil problem once and for all,'' said Bandaragama Rajapakse, a 18-year-old Sinhalese waiting in line. Anura Bandaranaike, president of the opposition Sri Lanka Freedom Party, said in Parliament: ``We stand solidly behind the forces today. Our hearts go out to them.'' Ranjan Wijeratne, the deputy defense minister, predicted the government eventually would be able to disarnits, unlike Indian troops, who moved large columns of soldiers,'' Wijeratne said. Indian soldiers were sent to Sri Lanka in July 1987 to oversee a surrender of arms by Tamil guerrillas as part of an India-brokered accord between Tamil groups and the government of Junius R. Jayewardene, Premadasa's predecessor. Most Tamil militias gave up their arms, but the Tigers soon reneged and took to the jungles. The Indians followed and were drawn into a two-year guerrilla war in which more than 1,100 of their soldiers were killed. The last Indian troops withdrew in March at Premadasa's request. Last year, Premadasa put down a two-year rebellion by radical Sinhalese who accused the government of making too many concessions to the ethnic Tamil minority. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the military as well as the government. Tamils, 18 percent of the population, claim discrimination in jobs, education and language. Tamil separatists have fought from the jungles and swamps since 1983. At least 13,000 people have been killed in the war. Premadasa, a Sinhalese, crushed the extremists in his own ethnic group. Their leaders were arrested and died in what were officially described as shootouts or escape attempts. Thousands of followers and suspected supporters were killed by pro-government bands that roamed the villages and countryside. ``We have learned from our past experiences and are now capable of destroying the rebels,'' Col. Parami Kulatunga said in the northern town of Vavuniya, one of the main sites of the latest fighting. Lakshman Jayakody of the opposition, a former defense minister, said: ``At the moment, I don't think we have any choice other than war.''

DOC.HEAD: Two-Time Artificial Heart Recipient Dies Of Multiple Organ Failure
DOC.TEXT: Michael Drummond, the first person to successfully receive an artificial heart as a bridge to transplant of a human heart, died Saturday night nearly two months after receiving a second artifical heart implant. Officials at University Medical Center said Drummond, 30, of Phoenix, died of multiple organ failure. His condition was downgraded to critical on Friday night after doctors discovered his liver had failed. Drummond was the first person to successfully undergo a bridge-to- transplant and recover from a subsequent heart transplant. He also was the youngest man to receive an artificial heart device when he had the Jarvik-7 artificial heart implanted Aug. 29, 1985. Drummond suffered a stroke, but recovered and received the heart of a 19-year-old Texas man nine days later. Drummond had been undergoing dialysis treatments for kidney failure for several weeks, and was fighting an infection. He had been placed on a ventilator to assist his breathing, but died at 7:35 p.m., said hospital spokeswoman Jan Howard. Drummond received his second artificial heart May 21. He developed complications in February after undergoing emergency gall bladder surgery and had developed right-sided heart failure. Dr. Jack Copeland, head of the hospital's transplant team, said in 1987 that Drummond was a ``modern hero who accepted the risk of the total artificial heart bridge to transplantation when no previous patient had survived.'' His remarks were made at a Washington, D.C., ceremony in which Drummond presented the artificial heart that had been implanted in his chest to the Smithsonian Institute's National Museum of American History. ``I guess I am sort of a part of history, but not by choice,'' Drummond said during the ceremony. ``It's possible 100 years from now that the artificial heart will be as routine as a blood transfusion.''

DOC.HEAD: Yellowstone Park Fire Grows, But Firefighters Get Upper Hand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with fire growing but expected to be contained by Monday; includes new quotes and other details.
DOC.TEXT: A fire burning for three days in Yellowstone National Park spread across 220 acres on Saturday, but officials were confident it could soon be fully contained. By Saturday night, firefighters had contained about 60 percent of the lightning-caused blaze in the park's northeastern section and expected to have it fully under control by Monday evening, said park spokeswoman Marsha Karle. ``We don't expect it to move anymore,'' she said. ``It may burn back on itself, but unless the winds increase or humidity drops dramatically, it looks like it's not going anywhere. We almost have a line all the way around it.'' About 315 firefighters were deployed to battle the park's first major blaze of the summer, Karle said. Ground crews were helped by drops of fire retardant and water from helicopters and airplanes over the lower east slopes of Mount Washburn and by cooler temperatures and light winds, she said. Crews have had difficulty gauging the parameters of the fire, which started Thursday afternoon and had spread to an estimated 100 acres by late Friday, she said. ``It's been very smoky and hard to see,'' Karle said. ``It's been hard to get real good fix because the terrain is steep, rocky and hard to get around.'' No structures have been threatened, but a couple of hiking trails in the area were closed.

DOC.HEAD: Six Injured in Finale of Bay City Fireworks Festival
DOC.TEXT: A 10-inch rocket misfired during the finale of the Bay City Fireworks Festival on Saturday night, igniting other fireworks in a pit area and injuring five workers and a policeman, police said. At least two of the six men were admitted to a hospital with burns, but the extent of their injuries was not immediately known. The injured include a Michigan State police detective, and one of the workers was treated and released, said Bay Medical Center spokeswoman Gerrie Wolverton. Spectators said at least one of the men was engulfed by flames. Gov. James Blanchard apparently had left the fireworks' pit in Veterans Memorial Park just minutes before a rocket exploded while being fired from a mortar tube at about 11 p.m., police said. ``It exploded just as it was clearing the mortar tube,'' said Linda Collier, a Bay City policewoman. ``It blew low and ignited three or four other firecracker shells near it.''

DOC.HEAD: Melee Erupts as Crowd Waits for 2 Live Crew Concert
DOC.TEXT: About 50 fans of the rap group 2 Live Crew rampaged Saturday night when a concert was canceled, smashing tables and chairs and hurling bottles at the stage, witnesses said. Several people suffered minor injuries, but no arrests were reported. Police declined to provide any details on the disturbance. More than three hours after the concert was to begin at the Longhorn Ballroom, an unidentified person announced over the public address system at 11:15 p.m. that the band would not appear if they did not get paid, witnesses said. Twenty minutes later, the band's stagehands began packing up their equipment. A man jumped up on the stage and demanded his money back, and the crowd of 540 turned surly when security guards dragged the man away, witnesses said. About 50 people turned violent, smashing the wooden chairs and tables, while most of the crowd spilled out of the building, witnesses said. Security guards soon forced the protesters outside. Several windows in the front of the building were broken by missiles and some cars in the parking lot were vandalized before some 50 police officers in riot gear arrived and dispersed the crowd, witnesses said. The ruckus lasted about 12 minutes. 2 Live Crew, whose album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has been ruled obscene by a Florida judge and banned from record shops in San Antonio, Texas, never came on stage. An estimate of the amount of damage was not immediately available. Earlier, a state district judge, Merrill Hartman, nullified a fire marshal's order forbidding the concert. The Dallas Fire Department moved Friday to shut the Longhorn, saying it was a private club that couldn't sell tickets for a public event without dance or theater permits.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Faces Crisis In Loss of Soviet And East European Aid
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam is being driven toward economic crisis by a large reduction in aid from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, its only major allies in the past decade. Aid from non-Communist countries began drying up when Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978, and it cannot turn to the International Monetary Fund or World Bank because of U.S. opposition. Commercial concerns have become paramount in Moscow and Communist rule has collapsed in Eastern Europe, so agreements extending aid in the name of ``socialist fraternity'' will not be renewed at the end of this year. ``Our relations were not balanced and not mutually beneficial,'' said Anatoly Voronine of the Soviet Embassy. ``We had to spend a lot of money for that friendship. We need to commercialize our cooperation.'' Jozef Hanculak, charge d'affaires of the Czechoslovak Embassy, said about 90 percent of Vietnam's credits had come from the Soviet bloc. He said the interest rate had been only 2 percent or 3 percent a year, but going international rates would apply to future credits. Prime Minister Do Muoi told the parliament June 28 that citizens must be more self-reliant and tighten their belts because foreign aid ``that we ... have relied upon for many years now is being reduced rapidly.'' Cheap imports and huge loans for state expenditures no longer will be available, he said. Vietnam signed a friendship treaty with Moscow shortly before invading Cambodia and has called the alliance the cornerstone of its foreign policy. The Kremlin now seeks better relations with Hanoi's archrival China, however, and has lessened support for Vietnam on political issues, including Cambodia. Voronine said military aid would be reduced significantly because Vietnam no longer is threatened. Diplomats said Vietnam's alliance with the former Soviet satellites was based solely on common ideology and was bound to collapse when the political and economic systems in those nations changed. ``Vietnam's relations with East European countries will be on new conditions,'' said ambassador Dietmar Grumbach of East Germany. ``This applies for economic, cultural and other fields of cooperation, because one thing is clear: The political and ideological bases of our countries are different.'' Vietnam has been expanding trade with Britain, Japan, South Korea and other non-communist countries and its military withdrawal from Cambodia in September improved relations with the European Community. Last year, France became the first EC country to resume aid, and in May, Italy pledged $97 million. The economy still may suffer severely because Vietnam cannot attract enough help to replace the Soviet aid that is ending, a senior government economist said, on condition of anonymity. He said the Soviets had abandoned some projects they started, and they and the East Europeans canceled some orders for Vietnamese goods. Foreign traders say a reduction in fertilizer supplies from the Soviet Union is hurting rice production and there are signs of problems caused by smaller deliveries of Soviet petroleum. Most of the 180,000 Vietnamese guest workers in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will be returning home as ``labor cooperation'' programs are ended or reduced. In 1986-1990, Moscow gave Vietnam about 10 billion rubles ($16.6 billion at the official rate of exchange) in credits for trade and technical assistance, Voronine said. He said about 3,000 Soviet technical advisers were in Vietnam, down from a peak of 8,000 to 9,000 in the early 1980s. Analysts say Vietnam cannot meet the demand of its old allies for trade, starting next year, in hard currency at world market prices. Trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe was about 60 percent of Vietnam's total in 1989, said government economist Tran Van Chu. Vietnam has obtained most of its cotton, steel and vehicles from the Soviet Union and many basic goods, such as construction materials and food, from Eastern Europe. ``Most everything we see in Vietnam today just isn't going to be around,'' said Christopher Bruton, a business consultant. He said Vietnam has an equivalent problem with its major exports to Eastern Europe, including agricultural products, clothing and apparel, because they are of low quality and other buyers are not interested. Carlyle Thayer, a Vietnam scholar, estimated Soviet military aid, vital to a nation with no armaments industry, totalled $1.3 billion last year. Moscow is said to have removed most combat aircraft from Cam Ranh Bay, once its largest overseas base, and Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said all Soviet troops would leave the country by 1992. Analysts said Vietnam might benefit from the change in the long run. ``The Soviets ditched a lot of cash and got very little out of it,'' Bruton said. ``Vietnam got shoddy products and technology. It was a disaster for both sides. Vietnam has to recognize now that it is a Southeast Asian nation and it lives and dies on its relations with the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma Has 324 AIDS Virus Carriers
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 Burmese have tested positive for the AIDS virus, the Burmese government said in its first report on the disease. The Health Department began blood tests in 1985 and found the first carrier of the AIDS virus in 1988, spokesmen told a news conference Thursday. A text of a state radio broadcast that quoted them was seen in Bangkok on Sunday. The spokesmen said that as of December 1989, 324 of the 25,701 people randomly tested were virus carriers. The carriers were mostly drug addicts. The spokesmen said no AIDS patients were being treated, suggesting none of the carriers has developed symptoms of the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Flash Floods Cause Havoc in Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Flash floods set off by record rains killed or injured 300 people in Vietnam's northern province of Son La, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. The report did not specify how many people died. It quoted initial reports that the floods ruined 1,140 acres of riceland, damaged hundreds of irrigation canals and 15 bridges. Prolonged rains reached a record of more than 27.5 inches in some areas over an unspecified period, said the report, dated Saturday and seen Sunday. Son La, which borders Laos, is not far from from the national capital, Hanoi.

DOC.HEAD: Monsoon Floods Kill 74 in India, Dislocate 500,000 in Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: Heavy monsoon rains over the past week in western and northern India have killed at least 74 people and washed away hundreds of houses, news reports said Sunday. In neighboring Bangladesh, about 500,000 people were either homeless or stranded because of floods. Press Trust of India said air force helicopters were dropping food packets to marooned villagers in western Rajasthan state where the rains caused the Jajori River to overrun its banks. The summer monsoon causes floods in many parts of the Indian subcontinent every year. In Bangladesh, where two major rivers of the subcontinent form a delta before emptying into the Bay of Bengal, floods are a perennial problem. In 1988, at least 1,400 people died because of flooding in Bangladesh.

DOC.HEAD: British Tourist Bus Flips Over, 36 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A tour bus carrying British vacationers to a holiday in Spain flipped on its side Sunday, injuring 36 people, authorities said. The accident occurred five weeks after a double-decker British tourist bus returning from Spain flipped over at high speed on the same highway, killing 11 people and injuring 61. Only one of those hurt in the latest accident was reported in serious condition. The accident occurred on a major north-south highway as the bus was bringing 67 passengers from Hamilton, Scotland, to Spain. The bus driver, who was not injured, said he lost control of the vehicle but did not know why, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Recommends More Aggressive Response To Breast Lumps
DOC.TEXT: Physicians need to act more aggressively on the initial complaints of women _ especially younger women _ who find lumps in their breasts, a study of breast cancer malpractice claims and lawsuits indicates. The study by the Physician Insurers Association of America found that in 69 percent of cases where claims were paid because breast cancer diagnosis was delayed, the patient had discovered the lump. ``The physician needs to be impressed by such findings and order follow-up studies,'' said the report. ``This study indicates that self-discovery often may be ignored, especially in younger women where the incidence of malignancy is thought to be less than in older women'' and is more difficult to detect, the study said. The study reviewed 273 paid claims reported by 21 member companies of the association. All of the cases involved a delay in diagnosis of breast cancer. Women with breast cancer have best chances of surviving when it is discovered and treated in earliest stages. The study, released at the association's annual meeting in May, was discussed by members of the study committee in telephone interviews last week. Though breast cancer is more common among older women, the study indicates that delayed diagnosis in younger women results in the majority of lawsuits. Nearly 70 percent of the cases involved women under age 50, and 40 percent were filed by women under 40. The most common reason for delay in diagnosis was that ``the physical findings at examination failed to impress the physician,'' the report said. This was the case for 55 percent of the women. The second most common reason, found in 35 percent of cases, was that mammogram reports were negative. In 14 percent, mammograms were inconclusive. ``Doctors have to be more suspicious of the incidence of cancer in the breast ... and can't depend entirely on the mammogram,'' said Dr. Sylvan H. Eisman, a distinguished professor emeritus of clinical medicine at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, who directed the study. The American Medical Association had no comment on the findings. The study suggests that a biopsy always follow any suspicious findings. ``It's foolish not to do it (a biopsy) if there's reasonable cause of suspicion,'' Eisman said. The study also found that family history was unknown in 37 percent of the cases, though women with a family history of breast cancer are at higher risk of getting the disease themselves. Lack of communication among physicians involved in a case also can contribute to delays in diagnosing cancer, ``as each often thinks the other is the responsible physician,'' the study said. The study stressed the importance of self-examination by women, thorough examinations by a physician and regular mammograms. The American Cancer Society recommends a mammogram for women at around age 35 and regular mammograms every one or two years beginning at age 40 and annually after age 50. Among American women, breast cancer is the leading type of cancer and is second only to lung cancer in cancer deaths. The cancer society estimates that breast cancer will be diagnosed in 142,000 women in the United States this year and will cause 43,000 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Invites Levy To Meet Him in Paris
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has invited Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy to meet with him next week in Paris to try to get Mideast negotiations started. Whether Levy accepts depends on his health, diplomatic sources told The Associated Press on Sunday. The foreign minister is recovering from surgery for a circulatory disorder. It would be the first substantive talks between the Bush administration and the new Israeli government. Baker will be in Paris for talks July 17-18 on German unification with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and the British, French, West German and East German foreign ministers. Baker suggested in a letter he sent to Levy on Thursday that they meet July 17 or 19. He told Levy he knew the foreign minister had a reputation as a ``problem-solver'' and described himself as one, as well, the sources said. ``We badly need a peace process in the Middle East,'' Baker said Sunday on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. He said he had proposed the Paris meeting with Levy ``to begin discussions to this effect.'' Baker's last attempt to open Mideast negotiations stalled in March over his attempt to persuade Israel to accept participation by Palestinian Arabs deported from the West Bank and others who had homes in East Jerusalem. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir objected to those Arab-approved provisions because he saw them as challenging Israel's retention of Jerusalem as its capital and the West Bank. Baker told Levy he was anxious to have a meeting in Paris provided the foreign minister's health permitted. The sources said Levy had not responded yet, and that a decision depended on what his doctors decide. ``Hopefully, he will be able to go,'' the sources said. The Israeli government has been eager for talks with the Bush administration, which lately has taken a cool stance toward it. U.S. strategy is to push the Israelis to accept Baker's formula for the elections Shamir proposed last year to hold among Palestinians on the West Bank and in Gaza. In the letter Baker reiterated the provisions Israel found objectionable and said they had been adapted at the behest of the Palestinians ``because we thought it might be helpful.''

DOC.HEAD: Dwarfs Lobby to End `Degrading' Fad
DOC.TEXT: Angela Van Etten uses the five D-words to describe the most bizzare barroom fad of the 1980s. ``It's dangerous, it's degrading, derisive ... dehumanizing ... and it engenders discrimination,'' she says. Ms. Van Etten's disgust is aimed at dwarf-tossing, the strange ``sport'' that evolved in Australia and became popular in this country a few years back. She is herself a dwarf, a vocal member of the Little People of America. And she is one reason there may be a sixth D-word for dwarf-tossing. Dead. Ms. Van Etten, a lawyer who writes law books in Rochester, N.Y., is one of several short-statured people who have lobbied relentlessly in favor of a bill to effectively ban dwarf-tossing in New York state. The bill, similar to one that became law in Florida last year, would ban the practice in any place that serves liquor. Since dwarf-tossing has never been terribly popular in places that don't serve liquor, the ban pretty much gives it the hook. The bill awaits Gov. Mario Cuomo's signature. He said last week that he was studying it and hadn't made up his mind. It may be moot. Members of Little People of America, the organization for dwarfs founded by actor Billy Barty in 1957, have kept a close watch on exhibitions of dwarf-tossing across the country. They say it has virtually stopped, at least for now. ``It may be a fad that's faded out,'' said Heidi Heinrich, an office manager in Tallahassee, Fla., who has been a national leader in the fight against dwarf-tossing. Ms. Heinrich is aware of only one exhibition of dwarf-tossing in recent months _ an event in South Carolina that occurred while the state Legislature was considering a bill to criminalize the practice. The bill was defeated. Dwarf-tossing, as the name suggests, is a practice in which people of average height pick up dwarfs and heave them as far as they can. It also has produced an offshoot _ dwarf-bowling, in which small people are put on skateboards and rolled into bowling pins. In many cases, the dwarfs are paid to take part. ``I find it somewhat hard to understand,'' Ms. Van Etten says, ``but I think people are willing to go along with it because the dwarfs agree to it.'' That, of course, is not reason enough for Ms. Van Etten or many other dwarfs, who say that all small people suffer from the acts of a few. ``It perpetuates the whole image that we're playthings _ you know, the jesters in the king's court,'' Ms. Heinrich said. Ms. Van Etten calls it ``intolerable, really, even if these people are willing to be thrown. If you picked out any other minority group, do you think it would last five minutes? Can you imagine a Jew toss? Or a black toss?'' Critics say the practice is not only offensive but dangerous. Many dwarfs have brittle bones to begin with, and even a strong human body wasn't made to be a projectile. Dwarf-tossing is believed to have begun in this country around 1985. It reached a peak of notoriety last year, when it was featured on an episode of television's ``L.A. Law.'' A dwarf lawyer on the show was put in the position of defending the practice in court. In real life, it's not easy to find anyone to defend dwarf-tossing. Promoters and practitioners tend to travel around and keep a low profile. One promoter who will gladly discuss the issue is Baird Jones of New York, but Jones approaches dwarf-tossing from a slightly unusual perspective. His dwarf-tossing contests were presented as avant-garde art _ a way of tweaking the values of mainstream America. Jones says dwarf-tossing is ``more akin to a lynching than anything else. That's what we were mocking. When we did it, we were saying, `Can you believe that in a civilized society this is occurring?''' For a while, it was all the rage in some of Manhattan's trendiest nightclubs. But no more _ the glitterati have gone on to more tasteful pursuits, such as nude juggling. ``I haven't done anything recently with it, because once that bill got started ... none of the clubs wanted it,'' Jones said. ``I've been turned down at all the clubs whenever I've proposed it.'' That suits little people just fine. ``I hope it's a passing threat and there will be movement on to other concerns,'' Ms. Heinrich said. ``This was just a first step toward making society realize that we deserve acceptance. We're not freaks.''

DOC.HEAD: Is Andrew Young Headed for Runoff for Georgia Governorship?
DOC.TEXT: Former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young remains a Democratic front-runner in his bid to become Georgia's first black governor, but experts see large hurdles in his path even if he finishes first in the July 17 primary. Young's problems include the unspoken issue of race, the likelihood of a runoff after the five-man primary and Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Miller, Young's leading white opponent, has won substantial support from blacks and liberal whites over the past 16 years as the state's lieutenant governor. While the primary campaign has been free of racial references, a Miller-Young runoff could produce racially polarized voting that would tip the election to Miller, said Atlanta pollster Claibourne Darden. ``Racism is there. It just hasn't been brought up,'' Darden said. ``And it won't be brought up by any opponent of Andy's. But Andy's black and Zell's white, and even a black-and-white TV shows that. It's inherent in the election. It never needs to be spoken.'' Georgia requires a runoff if no candidate receives more than 50 percent of the vote. But the law is under challenge in a federal court suit filed by black legislators and civil rights activists. A judge is scheduled to hear arguments beginning Monday. Young is not participating in the lawsuit. At one time, he opposed runoffs, but he now says they ensure the emergence of a strong Democratic nominee. For the moment, Young and Miller are nip-and-tuck for the lead, according to the latest poll, conducted last month by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. It showed Young and Miller with 30 percent each. State Sen. Roy Barnes, a lawyer courting the conservative and environmental vote, had 12 percent; state Rep. Lauren ``Bubba'' McDonald, a hardware store owner backed by state House leaders, had 6 percent; and former Gov. Lester Maddox had 4 percent. Young is hoping to accomplish in Georgia what L. Douglas Wilder did in Virginia last year when he became the nation's first elected black governor. And during the campaign, he has taken only glancing attacks from opponents _ despite eight years as mayor of Atlanta when he came under fire for his management style and for the city's crime rate and other urban problems. ``There's been a lot of carefulness not to make charges against Young that could be interpreted as racial,'' said Michael Binford, associate professor of political science at Georgia State University. ``The white candidates are really cautious. They don't want anything to appear racially motivated because they know they're going to need black voters in the fall.'' The most likely Republican challenger in November is state Rep. Johnny Isakson, an Atlanta real estate executive. Young, whose core support is among blacks and liberal whites, has attempted to capture the attention of conservative, white voters by telling businessmen in economically strapped areas he can recruit industry as easily for southern Georgia as he did for Atlanta. Blacks made up 21.8 percent of the state's registered voters in 1988, last year for which complete figures are available, but 24.2 percent of the population. Young also has taken pains to secure the votes of abortion rights advocates, reminding voters he is pro-choice. So is Miller. The campaigns are well financed. In figures released last month, Young's contributions were second only to Miller's _ $2.76 million compared with $3.68 million. Campaign spokesmen said about one-third of Young's money came from out of state. Disclosure reports showed the givers included: talk show host Oprah Winfrey, $10,000; entertainer Bill Cosby, $15,000; sportscaster Howard Cosell, $500; musician Herb Alpert, $5,000; and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, $1,000. Financial disclosure reports for June, released Friday, show Young has kept the most money for the final days of the primary campaign, with $464,581 on hand. Miller had $309,619 in cash, and Barnes had $221,725 left in the bank. Miller has made legalizing a state lottery one of his principal campaign issues. The Atlanta Journal-Constitution poll in June found 72 percent of those sampled favored a lottery. Young says he favors letting the people vote on a lottery but personally opposes the idea.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Can Keep Lime Green Porch
DOC.TEXT: A woman was ticketed because one of her neighbors was offended by her bright, lime-green porch _ but now she can keep her choice of paint because both the neighbor and the city have backed off. ``The green porch stays green _ I feel terrific,'' said Judith Lubeski. A city inspector ticketed Lubeski, 47, in May after receiving a complaint from an unidentified neighbor who took offense at the shade of green highlighting the otherwise white colonial-style house. But now the resident is unwilling to testify in court, which means Lubeski cannot be charged with a misdmeanor, city spokesman Doyne Jackson said Friday. According to Dearborn law, homes in a neighborhood must be similar in appearance. Jackson said the ordinance is meant to regulate the style of homes and garages and may need to be rewritten to clarify that there is freedom of choice in color. Until then, he said, ``if someone decides to paint their garage shocking orange and there is a citizen complaint, this could happen again.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Rockets May Be Used to Send Up U.S. Satellites
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has agreed to let Soviet rockets be used for launching commercial U.S. satellites, officials confirmed Sunday. Launches would be undertaken by a private Australian real estate company, the Cape York Space Agency, from a base in northern Australia operated by a U.S. firm, according to a report in Sunday editions of The New York Times. Confirming that account, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on the ABC television program, ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' that ``the president's made a decision that an initial launch can go forward.'' On another Sunday interview program, President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said, ``This doesn't have anything to do with the U.S. space program,'' which has recently seen a $1.5 billion orbiting telescope crippled by a mirror ground to the wrong formula and National Aeronautics and Space Administration engineers unable to fix a hydrogen fuel leak in its space shuttles. The Soviet rocket program is ``just another one'' of several commercial launching ventures operated by China, France and U.S. companies, Scowcroft told interviewers on the CNN program, ``Newsmaker Sunday.'' Baker and Scowcroft were interviewed in Houston where Bush and other leaders of the world's top seven industrial powers are holding their annual economic summit. The Bush administration already has permitted the launch of an American communications satellite from a Chinese rocket. According to the report in The Times, the National Space Council, chaired by Vice President Quayle, approved a set of recommendations under which a division of United Technologies Corp. would be granted an export license to operate a launch base at Cape York, Australia for the Australian company. Soviet Zenit rockets could be launched by 1995, with engineers supplied by the Soviet space agency Glavkosmos, the newspaper said. Cost of the enterprise was said to be $500 million. U.S. rocket suppliers were said to object to facing competition from a new quarter, and the space council's conditions were said to include provisions guarding against unfairly low pricing of the Soviet rockets.

DOC.HEAD: Assailant Stabs Israeli Policeman
DOC.TEXT: An assailant ambushed and stabbed an Israeli policeman in the back Sunday near a church in the walled Old City marking the legendary burial place of Jesus, police said. The officer, identified as Moshe Tadji, 24, was in moderate condition at Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital with a punctured lung after undergoing surgery to remove the knife, a hospital spokeswoman said. Police shut the city's stone-walled gates after the 11:00 a.m. attack for an hour and detained dozens of Palestinians in the area for questioning. The assault came on a day designated by Palestinian underground leaders in a leaflet for ``distinguished escalation'' as part of the 31-month-old uprising against Israel. Police Minister Roni Milo of the right-wing Likud bloc rushed to the scene from the weekly Cabinet session and vowed police would use tougher measures to prevent further attacks. ``We see this attack in a very grave light,'' Milo said on Israel radio. ``There are new methods of action that will be carried out as soon as possible,'' he added, without elaborating. Police and witnesses said Tadji, who routinely works in Jerusalem's square-mile old city, was ambushed by a youth with black curly hair and wearing blue jeans and a yellow shirt, outside the Holy Sepulcher church in the Christian Quarter. The church is held by Catholics to be the burial site of Jesus. Protestants believe the burial place is outside the walled city in a shrine called the ``Garden Tomb.'' Doctors later said they removed an 8-inch-long kitchen knife from Tadji's back and that he was in moderate condition, Hadassah spokeswoman Yael Bossem said. The area of the Holy Sepulcher has been a source of Arab-Jewish tensions following the settlement established by a group of armed Israelis in a nearby building in April. The Supreme Court later ordered most settlers evicted after strong protests from the United States, but allowed about 20 to remain pending resolution of a tenancy dispute in the building. Israel captured East Jerusalem, with the West Bank and Gaza Strip, in the 1967 Middle East war. Jerusalem was annexed shortly afterward. The city is home to more than 350,000 Jews and about 140,000 Palestinians. During the uprising, 723 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis and 45 Israelis have been slain by Arabs. Another 232 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs as alleged collaborators with Israel. Also Sunday, Israel reopened a Palestinian vocational college in Abu Dis in the West Bank as part of a plan to reopen colleges shut during the uprising to prevent unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iran and Egypt to Consider Restoring Ties
DOC.TEXT: Iran's foreign minister will visit Egypt amid signs the two countries are considering restoring ties, a report said Sunday. The state-owned Al Messa newspaper said in an unattributed story that Iran has sent Egypt a message of thanks for the supplies sent following the earthquake that killed about 40,000 people last month. ``I learned that Iran has sent a message to Egypt through Geneva, thanking it for its help sent to the victims of the earthquake,'' Al Messa's editor-in-chief, Samir Ragab, wrote in a front-page article. ``Relations between Egypt and Iran will improve in the coming days, and the Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati will visit Cairo in the next few days after accepting an invitation'' from his counterpart, Ragab said. Ragab gave no further details on the reported meeting. Iran severed diplomatic relations with Egypt in 1979 to protest its peace treaty with Israel signed in March of that year. Despite the absence of ties, Mubarak sent several planeloads of supplies for the Iranian victims of the killer earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: US Embassy Warns Americans To Stay Away From Nightclubs
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy has warned Americans to stay away from the city's nightclub district because of unconfirmed reports that Communist rebels may try to kill U.S. nationals there, a U.S. spokesman said Sunday. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said the advisory was issued after a bar owner received a letter last week, purportedly from the New People's Army, threatening attacks on Americans in the city's Ermita district. ``We don't know whether the letter is valid or not,'' said Schrager. ``But we have a policy of advising Americans every time we receive any indication of a threat.'' Relatively few Americans frequent bars in the Ermita district, located about two blocks from the U.S. Embassy. The district includes several foreign firms. Ermita, a high-crime center of drugs, prostitution and petty street crime, is popular with Australians, West Germans, French and Scandinavian tourists, who are easily mistaken by Filipinos for Americans. The U.S. Embassy estimates there are between 120,000 and 140,000 Americans in the Philippines, including 40,000 affiliated with the American military. At least eight Americans are believed to have been slain by the New People's Army since April 1989. Last month, suspected rebels kidnapped Peace Corps volunteer Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo. on the central island of Negros. Also last month, the United States suspended Peace Corps operations because of rebel threats. Swanson was abducted June 13 but U.S. officials learned of it only two weeks later after trying to contact him about the suspension order. On Friday, a statement purportedly from the Negros rebels said Swanson and a Japanese aid worker kidnapped in May would be released this month. The statement said both were safe and had been cleared of spy charges. If the statement was authentic, it would be the first public acknowledgement from the rebels that they were holding Swanson and the Japanese worker, Fumio Mizuno. The statement warned that Peace Corps volunteers would no longer be permitted to work on Negros because some of them had been spying for the Philippine military. Schrager said the United States welcomed reports that Swanson was alive but had no way of verifying whether the statement was really from the guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp
Summit Push On To Resolve Farm Subsidies Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is determined to resolve a nasty dispute between the United States and Europe over farm subsidies at this year's economic summit. Without a compromise on agriculture, the administration believes, an ambitious four-year effort to overhaul the global trading system could end in failure. Those talks, being held under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, hold out tremendous promise of expanding trade opportunities for American farmers and businesses by removing existing barriers and bringing more products under the rules of the global trading system. In an era when the United States has suffered through six consecutive years of $100 billion-plus trade deficits, it is no wonder that the administration is searching for ways to boost U.S. exports. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills paints failure of the trade liberalization talks in almost apocalyptic terms of ``gravely diminished prosperity'' for both rich and poor nations alike as countries turn inward and erect trade barriers. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, face an end-of-the-year deadline for conclusion with the final bargaining session scheduled for Brussels in early December. However, with only six months left, none of the major issues has been resolved. U.S. negotiators are seeking to phase out all trade-distorting farm subsidies, to dismantle barriers to trade in services, a high-growth area where the United States is extremely competitive and to crack down on copyright piracy, estimated to cost American companies $60 billion annually. But of all the issues, agriculture is seen as the key. That is because Third World countries have balked at agreeing to U.S. proposals on removing barriers to trade in services and beefing up their enforcement of copyright laws unless they win expanded markets for their farm products. The farm subsidy battle is also draining government treasuries with the cost to U.S. taxpayers and consumers put at $75 billion annually and the cost to the 12-nation European Community running an even higher $125 billion annually. The United States is pushing for a complete phase out of subsidies in three areas _ export subsidies paid by governments to make their country's products cheaper on world markets, domestic price supports paid to farmers to boost production and barriers erected to keep products out, thus boosting the price to a country's consumers. The European Community, however, has balked at this approach, expressing a willingness only to consider reducing the aggregate total of farm subsidies and charging that the U.S. proposals could mean pushing 2 million to 3 million of their less-efficient farmers off the land, a politically unacceptable result. The dispute over farm subsidies turned bitter at a May session attended by U.S. and European officials. Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official, told reporters in Houston that continued pressure by the United States would backfire and make it even harder to reach a compromise. ``If the pressure is exaggerated, it makes it more difficult to negotiate,'' Andriessen said. The United States, however, is holding firm to its position that it will accept nothing less than an agreement which addresses all three areas. The Bush administration has tried to paint the European Community as the lone holdout in the farm battle. But Japan is also holding back on the question of removing all market barriers, which would submit the protected Japanese rice market to foreign competition. About the only thing that is certain is that Bush will have his hands full in convincing his economic summit partners to come around to the U.S. position. Japan, West Germany, France, Britain and Italy all have reasons for protecting farm subsidies. At the economic summit, Bush can count only on Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney for full support for the U.S. position. But Hills said the United States has no intention of dropping its effort for global agricultural reform, seeing success here as the key to achieving ultimate victory with the total Uruguay Round. ``The Uruguay Round holds the promise at a magical moment in history of being the ultimate competitiveness machine. It will provide an enormous boost for emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and Latin America,'' she told reporters at a pre-summit briefing. ``It holds a real prize not only for us but for the vitality of the global trading system in the 21st Century.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp
Cowboys, Heat Hot Topics In Houston
DOC.TEXT: Who was that cowboy? Kabun Muto, head of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, delighted his American hosts by showing up at a Houston nightspot in full Western regalia, down to a string tie and Texas-size silver belt buckle. Muto fit right in at the Cadillac Bar, known for bar maids who pour tequila out of gun holsters and have shot glasses affixed to the bandoleers crisscrossing their chests. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, who along with his wife Georgette was hosting a dinner party at the bar for Muto, was wearing a pair of borrowed jeans because the former oil man from Houston had forgotten to pack his own for the summit.

``Houston's Hot!'' the billboards proclaim. No kidding. But the VIPs coming to town won't break a sweat. The seven world leaders are scheduled down to the minute during the three-day event, and summit director Fred Malek said Sunday only 18 minutes will be spent standing in the heat. ``We expect that the heat will not be an issue because almost every event will be conducted indoors,'' Malek said. Western leaders will have to sweat through an arrival ceremony at Rice University on Monday. Because of the heat, the schedule has been shortened, and the outdoor portion will last only 18 minutes. Houston highs have been in the low 90s with humidity of 80 percent. With some delight, however, Malek noted that Washington highs last week were over 100 degrees.

Oops. NASA, a hometown hero in Houston, has an elaborate exhibit at the economic summit's media center to tout its past glory and future endeavors. Like the Hubble Space Telescope. The exhibit prominently proclaims the Hubble ``potentially the most dramatic single advancement in astronomy since the invention of the telescope.'' ``And it still is,'' said Celeilla Coleman, a National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokeswoman. ``It's just a temporary setback. Wait and see, and they'll fix it.'' The $1.5 billion Hubble was launched April 24 and NASA announced June 27 that its two main mirrors would not focus properly. A manufacturing error was suspected, and a corrective shuttle mission will be required before the space telescope can produce the images it was supposed to capture.

At the press center set up for the thousands of reporters covering the summit, one enterprising group has moved the standard news release into the computer age. An organization with the imposing title of ``The Eminent Persons Group on World Trade'' put their message promoting global free trade talks on a floppy disk. For the computer illiterate, they thoughtfully provided a printed copy of all the information contained on the computer disk.

DOC.HEAD: Scenario For Hostage Release Under Consideration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `He spoke...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with source saying release not expected for several days. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `At least...'
DOC.TEXT: Iran has decided to use its influence with Shiite Moslem kidnappers to free one of 16 Western hostages they hold, and a scenario for the release is being worked out, a source close to the fundamentalist Hezbollah said Sunday. ``The decision was taken in Tehran to release the hostage. The details on where, when and how are now under consideration in Lebanon,'' the source said on condition of anonymity. The source would not speculate on who would be released, or answer any other questions. ``We have to wait for a communique (from the kidnappers),'' he said. Another source close to the command of Syrian troops in Beirut's Moslem sector said he did not expect a hostage to go free before the middle of the week. ``We haven't been contacted yet about arrangements of the release. It usually takes two to three days after such contact to have the hostage out,'' the source said. He also requested anonymity. The Shiite source spoke just before Israeli warplanes struck a Hezbollah base in southern Lebanon in their 14th air raid on targets in Lebanon this year. At least two people were killed and seven wounded in the raid on a position between the villages of Jarjou and Ein Bouswar, two to three miles north of Israel's self-designated security zone in southern Lebanon. It was not clear if the hostage-holders would cancel the reported plan for a hostage release in retaliation for the raid. Moslem fundamentalists accuse Western governments, especially the United States, of bias toward Israel and hold them responsible for Israel's actions against the Arabs. Hezbollah, or Party of God, is believed to be an umbrella for underground factions holding most of the Westerners. Newsmen and photographers maintained a vigil at their offices and outside major Syrian army positions, awaiting word from the kidnappers to confirm reports of an imminent hostage release. Hostages released in the past were turned over to the Syrian army command, driven to Syria and then flown from there to their homes. Their releases followed statements from the kidnappers announcing who would be freed and when. Syria is the main power-broker in Lebanon. It has 40,000 troops in northern and eastern provinces as well as Moslem west Beirut. But it has little influence on the hostage-holders. Tehran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported Saturday that a Western hostage would probably be released soon. It said that most likely the hostage would be one of the Europeans. The hostages include six Americans and 10 Europeans _ four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The 47-word report from IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, was attributed to unidentified sources. The headline read: ``A European Hostage May Be Released Soon.'' The report said the sources ``hinted that he is most probably a European national.'' A source close to the Syrian army command said that if any hostage were released, it would probably be the Irishman, Brian Keenan. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, refused to say why he thought Keenan, who also holds a British passport, would be the one. Keenan, 39, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked from his home to the American University of Beirut, where he taught English. Diplomats in Tehran said in recent interviews that Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has renewed a push to get the captives freed. No group has claimed the abduction of Keenan, of Belfast. But when American educator Frank Reed was released from captivity in April he said he had seen Keenan. Another American, Robert Polhill, also was freed in April, but he apparently was held by other kidnappers. Keenan's sister, Elaine Spence, told the British Press Association in London that she held hope her brother would be freed, but that no firm word was available yet. ``We have been talking on the telephone to the Foreign Affairs Department official in Dublin who said they are following up every possible line of inquiry, but they still have no news,'' she said from the home of her sister, Brenda Gillham, near Dundonald, Northern Ireland. ``We are getting prepared in case it is all true and we have to fly out to meet Brian,'' she said. ``But we are not getting our hopes raised too high. This has all happened before.'' An Irish government delegation visited Tehran in mid-June. An Irish Red Cross aid plane was the first to reach Iran after a June 21 earthquake that devastated northwestern provinces. After the release of Reed and Polhill, Iran asked for a reciprocal ``goodwill'' gesture from the United States. It suggested that Washington and other Western governments pressure Israel to free some 300 detainees in Khiam, in southern Lebanon, and provide firm word on the fate of four Iranians kidnapped by Lebanese Christians in 1982. Lebanese Christian officials say they have been killed, but Iran insists it has information they are still alive. President Bush has said he will not make deals for captives. Israel said it would not agree to any deal unless it involves freeing three servicemen captured by Shiite groups in southern Lebanon in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Scowcroft Defends China Mission
DOC.TEXT: National security adviser Brent Scowcroft on Sunday agreed with a leading Chinese dissident that Scowcroft's controversial secret mission to Beijing last year was a failure, at least so far. ``I think it's premature to say whether the mission was successful or not,'' Scowcroft said on CNN's ``Newsmaker Sunday'' television program. ``Within the time frame we hoped for, it was unsuccessful.'' Scowcroft was responding to a statement broadcast earlier Sunday from Fang Lizhi, a Chinese astrophysicist who spent more than a year in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing following China's brutal suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations last summer in Tiananmen Square. Lizhi, who recently was allowed to go to Britain, said ``I do not believe that the sending of a special presidential envoy last December was a successful tactic.'' Lizhi, in a prerecorded interview broadcast on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, called for close monitoring of China's human rights record. ``There still remain a large number of students held in custody or in prison,'' he said. ``Some have already been sentenced. These cases still need to be solved. Moreover, we must not forget those who have been imprisoned now for more than 10 years, people like Wei Jing-Sheng.'' In the wake of the Tiananmen, President Bush announced sanctions and suspended high-level contacts with the Chinese government. But he secretly sent Scowcroft to Beijing, saying later it was important for China not to feel isolated. At one point Secretary of State James A. Baker III denied there had been any such missions, and later was forced to admit he had lied. Scowcroft, here with Bush in advance of Monday's opening of the Western economic summit, said China's transition to an open society, interrupted by Tiananmen, ``has perhaps resumed if you call the release of Fang Lizhi part of that process.'' But Scowcroft said the administration still wanted China to ``release all those who were peaceful protesters, stop jamming the Voice of America and resume the course they were on.'' ``Let's not put those as conditions'' for the United States to relax its remaining sanctions against China, he added. ``But there are strong limits as to what the United States can do'' if China does not change. Bush on Saturday said he would not stand in the way of a planned $5.2 billion loan from Japan to China.

DOC.HEAD: Reigning Pit-Spitter Licks Competition
DOC.TEXT: Rick ``Pellet Gun'' Krause did it again _ hawking a seed 50 feet, 8{ inches to win the International Cherry Pit Spitting Championship. Krause captured his eighth title Saturday by winning the 17th annual event at Tree-Mendus Fruit Farm near Eau Claire. On the women's side, four sisters placed first, second, third and fourth. Krause, a 36-year-old substitute school teacher from Sparta, was the champion spitter in 1980, 1983, 1984, 1985 and every year since 1987. His personal best is 72 feet, 7 inches. ``Its just a lot of fun. I like doing crazy things and this ranks up there,'' he said. The key to a good spit, he added, is a clean pit. Krause's prizes included apples off a tree at Tree-Mendus for a year, a weekend at a hotel, a dinner and $10 worth of gas. While this year's spit of a tart cherry pit fell short of his longest, the victory was the sweetest. His 12-year-old son, Brian, won the youth division with a spit of 35 feet, 3 inches. Fred Fernau, 21, of Stevensville finished second with a spit of 48 feet, 5 inches. It was a family affair in the women's division, won by Irene Grambow, 28, of East Lansing at 30 feet, 5 inches. Her sister, Eileen Meeks of Brown City, was second at 30 feet, 2 inches; another sister, Dee Ann Henn of Okemos, was third at 28 feet, 9 inches; and sister Helene Mueller of Burton was fourth, 26 feet 4 inches. Contest organizers supplied a rack for pit spitters with dentures, to catch the flying teeth.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Days Before Primaries, Judge to Hear Arguments in Runoff Challenge
With AM-Georgia Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Just eight days before Georgia's primary elections, a federal judge will hear arguments Monday in a lawsuit alleging that the state's majority-vote rule is racially discriminatory. A group of black legislators and civil rights officials, led by state Rep. Tyrone Brooks, has challenged the system that requires a runoff if one candidate fails to receive a majority of the votes cast in elections for state offices. The class action suit seeks to immediately impose a plurality system, whereby the candidate receiving the most votes would be the winner even if he or she got fewer than half. A hearing is scheduled before U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman. If imposed before the primary, such a method would be seen as helping former Atlanta mayor Andrew Young in his bid against four others in the Democratic gubernatorial race. Young, trying to become Georgia's first black governor, is thought to have a better chance to win a plurality on July 17 than a majority in a two-candidate runoff. Current polls put him roughly equal with the leading white candidate, with each getting about 30 percent support. Young, however, is not backing the lawsuit. The state has argued that the 1964 law, passed in the wake of national civil rights legislation, was not rooted in racism but instead represents a longstanding commitment to the concept of majority voting. Attorney General Michael Bowers chraged, in briefs filed last month, that the suit was an attempt to ``manipulate'' the governor's race. Laughlin McDonald, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney representing the plaintiffs in the case, said he will present evidence that the Georgia system was established as a way to maintain the power of the state's white Democratic leadership and disenfranchise blacks. ``The white Democratic leadership ... regards it as very critical,'' he said Friday. ``If you go to a plurality, it will drive out the white majority.'' Lawyers in the attorney general's office who are involved in the suit did not return phone calls for comment late last week. Brooks said Friday that legislative debate at the time of the bill's passage focused on its impact on blacks, and that the results of elections in ensuing years have provided ample evidence that the majority requirement discourages black candidates. ``We're going to do our best to demonstrate to Judge Freeman that when the statute was enacted the intent was to keep blacks out of office,'' Brooks said. ``We intend to show that because of the runoff we've been kept at the bare minimum of the elected officials,'' he said. Brooks brushed aside criticism that the suit was timed to aid Young. He said he has been trying to eliminate the runoff system since 1984 but has been turned back by his fellow lawmakers. ``No matter when you file it, it's going to impact on some election cycle,'' Brooks said. ``We have elections every two years. We didn't see any reason not to file it this year.'' McDonald rejected the notion that the concept of majority voting was an American tradition. ``To say that it is American and constitutional is simply not so,'' he said. ``The Bill of Rights says that minorities do have rights.'' If there were strict adherence to majority voting, he said, ``we would never have had desegregated schools because that's not what the majority in the states wanted.'' The state has argued that the case should be dismissed, or moved to another judicial circuit, because Brooks has another suit pending against the state's system of electing Superior Court judges. The state contends two cases overlap.

DOC.HEAD: Game Show Host Bill Cullen Dies At 70
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cullen, a television personality and game show host whose career spanned such hits as ``I've Got a Secret,'' ``The Price is Right'' and ``The $25,000 Pyramid,'' has died of lung cancer at age 70. Cullen, who died Saturday at his home in Bel Air, appeared on radio and television game shows from 1944 to 1988, With his crew cut and heavy-frame glasses, he became a familiar face as a panelist on CBS's ``I've Got A Secret'' from 1952 to 1967. He also was host of the original ``Price is Right'' from 1957 to 1964 on NBC and later on ABC. ``Bill was the ultimate host,'' said colleague Dick Clark. ``He had great humor, intelligence and humanity. Most of all he had the great talent of making his job look easy.'' ``He was the best,'' said Clark, who was master of ceremonies for ``The $10,000 Pyramid,'' while Cullen was host of the nighttime version, ``The $25,000 Pyramid.'' ``He certainly created the yardstick of professionalism by which all other MCs could follow,'' said Cullen's manager, George Spota. Cullen's game show resume also includes ``Three on a Match,'' ``Pass the Buck,'' ``To Tell the Truth'' and ``The Joker's Wild.'' He made the cover of the national edition of TV Guide seven times between 1954 and 1984, including twice in one month in 1964. Cullen was working in a garage in Pittsburgh in 1939 when he got his first job in broadcasting as an unpaid assistant disc jockey. He later became a regular announcer earning $25 a week. In 1943, Cullen moved to New York and became a staff announcer with the CBS Radio Network. A year later, he became announcer for the ``Winner Take All'' game show. Cullen's first television game show was ``Give and Take,'' a 1952 question-and-answer show on which he was co-host with John Reed King. ``He's spent more time on broadcast air, radio and television, than anyone else in the business,'' said Spota. Bob Stewart, who produced ``The Price Is Right'' for eight years, said Cullen was in a class by himself. ``Professionally, nobody I ever worked with was his peer,'' said Stewart, a friend for 35 years. ``There was nobody like him nor will there every be. Off camera, he was the same kind of lovable, fun, mischievous guy you saw on television.'' ``I hope never to be a big, really big, star,'' Cullen told The New York Times in 1958. ``I may never be one in any case. But I've seen too many big names burn themselves out on television.'' Cullen is survived by his wife, Ann.

DOC.HEAD: Alabanian Leadership Appears Unshaken
With AM-Albania, Bjt
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Albanian leader Ramiz Alia appears unshaken in his determination to keep tight control over his limited reform program, despite unprecedented popular resistance to decades of harsh Communist rule. The crisis began when thousands of discontented Albanians crowded foreign embassies hoping for a chance to begin new lives in the West. Others took to the streets of the capital, Tirana, in anti-government protests. But by Sunday, the turmoil generated by the asylum-seekers had not escalated into the kind of unrest that toppled Communists elsewhere in Europe. Potentially more threatening to the regime was dissatisfaction with its slow, tentative approach to changing the centrally controlled economy, which has caused Albania's standard of living to lag far behind its neighbors'. Alia began tinkering with the Stalinist economic, political and social systems he inherited even before the rush on foreign embassies in Tirana. Under a reform program begun in May and recently accelerated, citizens who previously had no hope of traveling abroad are now entitled to passports. A ban on religion has been lifted, the death penalty has been abolished for defectors and modest economic retooling has been promised. The country, long considered the hermit of Europe for its isolationist policies, has signaled willingness to restore ties with both superpowers. It plans to join the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe after being the only nation on the continent to boycott it. But Alia has offered far fewer reforms than Communists in other Eastern European countries such as Hungary and Bulgaria, who voluntarily abolished their monopoly on power and introduced multiparty democracies. Alia told a special session of the Communist Party Central Committee called in part to deal with the embassy crisis that the party would remain supreme. ``What is of fundamental importance is the fact that the masses should be led by the party,'' Alia told the meeting over the weekend. His comments avoided any reference to even limited political plurality. While the Central Committee approved personnel changes in the party and government, Alia's authority appeared unshaken. Several longtime Politburo members were replaced with younger men believed closer to his way thinking. The naming of Hekuran Isai as interior and police minister, however, seemed to indicate a determination to deal harshly with any challenge from the street of the kind that ended Communist rule in Romania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany. Isai had held the post under Enver Hoxha, the founder of Communist Albania and Alia's predecessor. The choice disappointed those hoping for Central Committee appointees not associated with past repression. Police sealed off embassy row over the weekend from new asylum-seekers, but it appeared they had been ordered to keep a low profile and avoid further street confrontations as the leadership sought to weather the storm. As part of that strategy, authorities agreed Saturday to let the more than 5,000 asylum-seekers emigrate under foreign supervision. The leaders clearly hoped that sealing the embassy district and providing free access to passports would halt another rush on the diplomatic missions and end the threat of unrest.
