Alia also announced limited economic reforms to the Central Committee meeting calculated to alleviate low living standards, lack of luxury items and shortages of staples _ all of which have generated widespread dissatisfaction. He announced wage increases of as high as 20 percent in some cases and said tradesmen and shopkeepers could once again work for themselves, rather than the state. Such moves may be too little too late, however, particularly under liberalized travel laws allowing more of the population of 3.2 million to compare their Spartan existence to life in the West. While some of the asylum-seekers appeared motivated by frustration over political repression, others were clearly disillusioned by their scramble to make ends meet and ready to risk all for a better economic life. One of the would-be emigres, in a telephone interview with Hungarian state radio, said he ``just can't make a living'' in Albania. The 28-year-old man said he worked as bricklayer, a chauffeur and a lathe operator for $60 dollars a month _ not enough to support his family.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Jahn, based in Vienna, has reported on Eastern European developments for The Associated Press since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Chopper Crashes During Rescue Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT that chopper crashed Sunday, sted Saturday.
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter en route to the site of a plane crash slammed into the side of a mountain Sunday, and the fate of the four people aboard was unknown, officials said. The plane crashed Thursday on a domestic flight, killing eight of the 12 people aboard. The four suvivors were airlifted off a mountainside on Saturday, the first day weather conditions permitted a search. Their conditions were not immediately known. The rescue helicopter, which was sent to recover bodies and pieces of wreckage from the downed Douglas Airways plane, crashed while flying to the plane crash site, 35 miles northwest of Port Moresby.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Looking to West for Credits to Help Reforms
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is worried his country cannot make the painful leap from a closely controlled economic system to a market-driven version without Western help. His quest for financial aid will be a major issue at the seven-nation summit of industrial powers that opens Monday in Houston. But it's a two-part issue: Not only is there the question of how much the other industrial giants can or want to do, but also the matter of what a huge cash infusion would accomplish in the Soviet Union. There is no doubt Gorbachev wants help. He has made that clear in public as well as in recent private letters to President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The leaders of West Germany and France are advocating that the industrial powers approve aid worth $15 billion to bolster reforms and help Moscow meet payments to foreign firms. The Soviet Union traditionally has been punctual in meeting payments, but recent delays have started to erode confidence among foreign investors. Bonn already has approved an unconditional loan of $3.1 billion, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl is apparently growing impatient with opposition from other leaders to the Soviet aid plan. Bush so far has been reluctant to agree to a massive aid program until Soviet authorities move more decisively from a planned to a market economy. Estimates of how much money would begin to stabilize the Soviet economy range from $5 billion to $20 billion _ colossal compared to what Eastern European countries have received to restructure their economies, but modest given the size of the Soviet economy and its relatively small foreign debt. Moscow's balance-of-payment deficit now tops $2 billion, nearly half it owed to West German companies. Part of the West German credit is expected to be used to pay overdue bills. Inability to keep food stores stocked has already forced Moscow to spend an extra 3 billion rubles ($500 million) on food imports. And more aid is thought necessary if the Soviet Union is going to leap from a centrally planned to a market economy. Without Western cash, the move to the market could inflict hardship on the population and more social pressure on Gorbachev. Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov told the Supreme Soviet parliament in late May that the consumer market was ``destitute.'' Ryzhkov, presenting a plan for what he called a ``regulated market economy,'' warned that if trends continued ``many crucial decisions, unpopular as they are, will meet an even more embittered response.'' The Soviet economy is plagued by inflation and a huge budget deficit. In the first four months of this year, ethnic unrest and strikes caused the loss of an estimated 10 million man-hours. Pro-market reforms are likely to drop production further as unprofitable businesses go bankrupt. Still, there is hope that Western aid could help keep store shelves stocked and bolster people's faith that reforms will improve their lives. Soviet reformers are stymied not only by consumer shortages, but by a 70-year legacy of central planning that allowed only limited forms of individual enterprise. They are also hampered by decades of propaganda portraying capitalist economies as ridden with poverty, unemployment and vicious competition. Gosplan, the central agency responsible for running the economy, has concluded outside aid is needed, but has not made public a blueprint for how to spend Western money. Delegates to the 28th Communist Party Congress under way in Moscow have shown deep hostility to private property and individual ownership of factories, although some delegates did support Western help. ``Aid is a good idea. There are big changes in our economy, but we can't seem to set things straight. Help could make things better and we should accept this offer,'' said delegate Nikolai V. Mikhug, a worker from a tube-rolling factory in the Ural Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Communism's Collapse in Europe to Overshadow African Summit
DOC.TEXT: African leaders open an annual summit meeting Monday that will be overshadowed by the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. Noting political shake-ups from the Baltic to the Balkans, the 51-member Organization of African Unity ministerial council resolved that its governments pledge themselves to ``full democratization'' in a continent dominated by one-party states. When they gained independence from European colonial powers, many African Unity countries adopted political systems like those entrenched at the time in Eastern Europe. ``A permitting political environment which guarantees human rights and the observance of the rule of law would assure high standards of probity and accountability on the part of those who hold public office,'' the ministers declared in a draft statement for the summit. The heads of state meet Monday through Wednesday for their 26th conference. Main issues for discussion will be efforts to end South Africa's racial policy of apartheid, the member states' foreign debts, the growing plight of refugees and the Middle East. But the winds of change in Eastern Europe ``constitute major parameters which should govern Africa's collective thinking about the challenges and options before her in the 1990s and beyond,'' the draft declaration said. It was prepared by foreign ministers who set the summit agenda during a three-day meeting last week. On the issue of South Africa, the report welcomes President F.W. De Klerk's recent reforms. But it also noted that ``those changes only tinker with the system and fall far short of a common objective of totally dismantling apartheid.'' The ministerial council said that until Pretoria commits itself to abolishing apartheid, the international community must continue to presure South Africa with economic sanctions. The ministers painted a grim picture of an African continent that is ``disintegrating.'' Food output is down and population growth up, the draft notes. Per capita income has plunged and exports have dropped. Standards of living have fallen in tandem with spending on health, housing, education and other social services. By the end of 1989, foreign debt had swollen to $257 billion. The ministers proposed that foreign powers restructure their economies to help poorer nations. Apart from events in Eastern Europe, a highlight of the summit will be an address by Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress guerrilla group that is at the forefront of efforts to end apartheid in South Africa. Mandela, 71, who was freed from a South African prison in March, is expected to thank African leaders for supporting the ANC during the 27 years he was incarcerated. Lask week in Uganda, Mandela and three African presidents discussed proposals aimed at hastening an end to South Africa's white rule. They said they would present the proposals to the summit.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Call Solidarity Legislators to Task
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa and Solidarity's rank and file accused the trade union's Parliament members of forgetting their roots Sunday at a meeting in the Gdansk Shipyard where the labor group was born. The six-hour meeting, which drew more than 2,000 workers and their families, was attended by Solidarity parliamentary leader Bronislaw Geremek and 160 of the lawmakers swept to office by union endorsement last year. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, under increasing attack over the government's painful economic reform measures, turned down a request to attend. Instead, he asked workers to come talk with him Wednesday. Held in the workers' hall where the East bloc's first independent trade union was formed in 1980, the meeting highlighted the rift between workers in the provinces, and the Solidarity-led government in Warsaw. It took place one day after Mazowiecki and Walesa met at a secluded monastery outside Warsaw and announced a truce in their political war over the pace of reforms in Poland. But the prime minister remained embattled. Representatives of Poland's 2.5 million private farmers have given him until Wednesday to agree to guaranteed minimum farm prices or face a nationwide road blockade. In a partial answer to Walesa's calls for faster political change, Mazowiecki ousted three former Communists from his Cabinet Friday and agreed to early parliamentary and presidential elections. Only about 100 of the 260-strong Solidarity parliamentary caucus, known as the Citizens Parliamentary Club, failed to come to Gdansk to meet with the shipyard workers. Some of those who rejected the invitation had earlier cited the aggressive tone in which it was framed. About 400 people jammed the hall Sunday and more than 2,000 listened outside over loudspeakers as Walesa addressed the lawmakers, not mincing words. ``Today I hear voices saying, `Who dared to invite the parliament deputies?'' he said. ``Doesn't this hall have the right to call you? It has. You started from here.'' Walesa said Parliament has to be accountable to voters: ``The question is whether you are going to be above us ... or should you first come back and ask what's most important _ not in your opinion, but in the opinion of those who elected you?'' He acknowledged the deputies were working ``day and night'' but said there was a lack of public explanation of their decisions. ``One blow from the farmers or the miners will put all those laws into the wastebasket,'' Walesa said. The Solidarity chairman, in his only reference to the talks Saturday, said he and Mazowiecki discussed how they fell into their current dispute. ``We said bluntly: Because we never talked about what was supposed to happen after communism, how we would accomplish the second stage, how we would go along with Poland without forgetting where we came from,'' he said. ``Today we must return to the roots.'' Workers from the Baltic port city's three main shipyards invited Parliament members to tell them workers' complaints about the 10-month-old Solidarity-led government. ``The government is late with everything, and ordinary people feel helpless facing poverty,'' said Zbigniew Lis, leader of the Solidarity chapter in the Gdansk Shipyard. According to Lis, workers want Communists punished for past economic and political crimes; the elimination of companies created by the Communist elite from state property; and a slowdown of the recession caused by the austerity measures. Geremek told the workers it was not surprising they were upset by the difficulties they face. ``Whoever promises there will be a speeding up in public welfare is speaking an untruth. We are at the beginning of a difficult road and we must not make any false promises,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Facing Man He Once Complimented
DOC.TEXT: When Sen. Jesse Helms was a television commentator in the 1960s, he made a flattering assessment of the first black student to enter Clemson University. Now the conservative Republican is being challenged in his re-election bid by that same man _ Democrat Harvey Gantt, former mayor of Charlotte. In 1963, Helms called Gantt sincere in his desire to obtain an education and praised him for resisting ``the pose of a conquering hero.'' Helms heaped praise on Gantt while directing criticism at James Meredith, who had become the first black to enter the University of Mississippi a few months earlier, an event that sparked a major riot. Meredith, who was wounded during a freedom march in Mississippi in 1965, has changed his views markedly since then and today serves on Helms' Washington staff. He calls integration a ``con job'' and blames liberals for blacks' social problems. In his commentary 27 years ago, Helms said Gantt ``has demonstrated that he knows a thing or two about human nature, and, more important to our way of thinking, that he is sincere.'' The editorial was broadcast Jan. 29, 1963, on WRAL-TV in Raleigh, The News and Observer of Raleigh reported Sunday. ``He has stoutly resisted the pose of a conquering hero for the forces of integration,'' Helms said. ``He simply wants, he says, to be an architect _ and Clemson is the only college in South Carolina that can teach him how to be one. ``He has rejected the fanfare and trappings of the NAACP. He has turned away from the liberal press and television networks which would glorify him. He has refused to make pompous speeches and statements.'' ``If ever a man put his best foot forward, Harvey Gantt has done so. His conduct will not cause South Carolinians to relish court orders relating to integration. But he has done a great deal, probably more than he himself realizes, to establish respectful comunications across sensitive barriers in human relations.'' Helms said Gantt and Meredith were ``a study in contrasts.'' ``There is a difference in James Meredith and Harvey Gantt _ Meredith as a man handpicked as the showpiece of forced integration, Meredith as a man who never quite persuaded anybody that he was really interested in an education, Meredith as a man constantly and piously parading before the microphone and television cameras,'' Helms said.

DOC.HEAD: Test Shows Weather Radar Malfunctions _ Report
DOC.TEXT: A test found the National Weather Service's new computerized radar storm detection system breaks down frequently and is less reliable than the 33-year-old system now in use, a newspaper reported Sunday. Results of the six-month test rate the 1957-vintage radar system as 10 times more reliable than the new equipment, called NEXRAD, The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer reported Sunday. The test results were obtained under the Freedom of Information Act by the union representing weather service employees, the National Weather Service Employees Organization, it said. The test was conducted by the Air Force from March to August 1989 in Oklahoma. The 118-page report said the new radar malfunctioned every 1.9 days, while the existing radar, called WSR-57, breaks down on average every 14 days. The Air Force testers said failures ``critically degraded the effectiveness of NEXRAD'' because they occurred during periods when forecasters especially depend upon radar to detect severe storm patterns. ``Many times in severe weather episodes, when the operators needed the system to support critical warning operations, the system was not available,'' the Air Force said. The testers said the WSR-57 has ``a demonstrated reliability approximately 10 times greater than the demonstrated reliability of the NEXRAD tested.'' Some 120 NEXRAD units, which can measure wind speed and direction and rain volume in a storm, are the centerpiece of a $1 billion modernization of the weather service scheduled for the 1990s. William Read, head of a team investigating the weather service's actions during the June 14 storm that caused flash flooding in eastern Ohio and killed 26, said the conventional radar at Akron-Canton was unable to determine the storm's severity in time to post a warning. Don Sarreals, special assistant to the NEXRAD program office, said the weather service is committed to modernization despite the test results. ``The program is supported and we are proceeding to install the radar,'' Sarreals said. ``We're making progress as rapidly as we can. When you're building something for the first time, you encounter various obstacles.'' He said the first operational NEXRAD will be installed in October near Oklahoma City. ``It's going to go through a vigorous testing period before it's turned over to the government and commissioned,'' Sarreals said. Most problems have been encountered in the computers that interpret weather data obtained by the radar unit, he said. ``The key to the thing is the computer, that's what makes it unique,'' Sarreals said. ``It's the computer that can dig into the data.'' In the eastern Ohio flooding, meteorologists were unable to determine the potential rainfall in the thunderstorms appearing on conventional radar, Sarreals said. ``You have to make estimates for rainfall now, which are basically done by humans,'' he said. ``A computer with a high-speed processor will dig into that with NEXRAD.''

DOC.HEAD: KCAL Pulls `Dick Tracy' Cartoon Off Air
DOC.TEXT: Under pressure from Asian and Hispanic groups, a television station has decided to pull the 1961 ``Dick Tracy'' cartoon series because two characters are considered ethnic stereotypes. The Disney-owned KCAL had scheduled a 13-week run of the cartoons to coincide with Disney's release last month of the ``Dick Tracy'' movie. The series ran four weeks before Asian and Hispanic groups complained about the characters Jo Jitsu and Go Go Gomez, two detectives who helped Tracy fight crime. Jo Jitsu has buck teeth, squints through glasses and mispronounces the letter ``r.'' Go Go Gomez wears a sombrero and takes frequent siestas. ``It should have been obvious from the very beginning that the show was offensive,'' said Raul Ruiz, a professor of Chicano studies at Cal State Northridge. KCAL said in a statement that the series had been reviewed before it was broadcast and was not deemed offensive because the characters were positive images. ``It's not our intention to offend anybody,'' said KCAL program director Matt Cooperstein.

DOC.HEAD: After Cold War, US Finds Economic Power Matters Most
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The United States, undisputed leader of the free world for four decades of Cold War, is adjusting to a new era when economic power counts more than military might. The adjustment process will be nowhere more apparent than in Houston as President Bush plays host beginning Monday for the annual economic summit meeting of the world's seven richest industrial democracies. Where the Western allies were once willing to let the United States set the agenda, the summit countries seem willing, even eager, to chart their own courses now that America's nuclear umbrella no longer seems crucial. ``1990 is the first year after the end of the Cold War,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, an international expert with the Council on Foreign Relations. ``It is a time when the American nuclear surplus will be less and less important and the American fiscal deficit will be more important.'' America is still the wealthiest of the wealthy when measured in terms of the $5 trillion in goods and services it produces annually. But Japan, now second with a $3 trillion economy, has been rapidly closing the gap. Some economists believe it could surpass the United States by the year 2000. Japan has already replaced the United States as the world's largest creditor country, reflecting its global investment clout. America, which began the 1980s as the world's largest creditor country, is now the biggest debtor. The transformation occurred largely because Americans transferred billions of dollars into foreign hands to pay for imported cars, television sets and other consumer goods. Forced now to rely on foreigners to finance its economy to the tune of about $10 billion a month, the new economic reality has spurred great domestic debate over whether the United States is losing control of its destiny to foreigners. Bush finds himself at odds with a number of the summit countries on a variety of issues at this year's summit, ranging from aid to the Soviet Union to cleaning up the global environment _ and trying to keep a nasty battle over farm subsidies from scuttling an effort to reform the world trading system. If the farm subsidy fight is not resolved, some analysts fear that the Cold War could very well be followed by a global trade war as more and more countries fall to squabbling over trade imbalances and erect protectionist barriers to keep imports out. ``As the compelling drive of the Soviet threat no long forces the West to work together, the economic forces could drive them apart,'' said Robert Hormats, a vice president at Goldman Sachs and a former U.S. ``sherpa,'' the top aide who prepares the summit agenda for the president. The huge U.S. budget deficit has long been a sore point with America's summit partners who contend that America's profligate borrowing needs have driven up world interest rates. Now that U.S. defense spending is no longer seen as critical to keeping world peace, the size of the budget deficit is likely to be even more of an irritant. Just before the summit, Bush reversed his opposition to tax increases as a way of solving the deficit problem. While that change of heart drew catcalls from conservatives in the United States, many foreign officials have breathed a sigh of relief. They view getting the U.S. budget under control as a critical step in solving some of America's more nettlesome economic problems as well as providing Bush with sorely needed resources to play a more active role on the world stage. Last year, for the first time, Japan replaced the United States as the world's largest donor of official foreign aid. The U.S. government, constrained by the budget deficit, has provided what many considered to be rather modest amounts to help in the economic transformation of former communist countries in Europe. Some foreign leaders see America's budget problems as the real reason Bush is dragging his feet on giving direct economic support for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform efforts. Bush is coming to the summit with one new initiative, seeking support from the other leaders for a U.S. plan to pour economic aid into fledgling democracies in Latin America _ similar to the assistance being offered former communist countries in Europe. That Bush proposal has been seen as a hopeful sign that the United States, while no longer able to dominate the economic agenda, will not draw inward in the coming decade. ``Our credibility has been damaged by unwillingness to provide even modest resources to support democratization in Eastern Europe and Latin America,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research group. ``Budget correction would enable the United States to become a serious global player and world leader again.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Martin Crutsinger has covered economic issues in Washington for The Associated Press since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Serial Killer in Virginia Slayings
DOC.TEXT: The slayings of six young people and the disappearance of another young couple in eastern Virginia may have been the work of a serial killer, police said. All four unsolved cases involve the slaying or disappearance of young people who were traveling by car in isolated areas. One crime has occurred annually between April and October since 186, but none has occurred this year. ``They're pretty much convinced it's a serial killer,'' said Mark Johnson, a College of William and Mary police detective who has investigated the 1986 slayings of a student at the college and her friend. ``We're just waiting for September or October because we all agree that's when it will happen again,'' Johnson said. ``Basically, they think it's a serial killer,'' agreed Margie Lauer, whose 21-year-old son, Daniel, was one of the slaying victims. Mrs. Lauer said FBI and state police agents have told her in recent weeks ``they felt it was all connected.'' ``We were expecting something like this,'' Kathy Knobling, stepmother of another slaying victim, said Sunday after accounts of the police theory were published in area newspapers. She is a spokeswoman for a group of the victims' relatives and friends. The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star newspapers, in their combined Sunday edition, quoted an unidentified souce as saying that the killer could be someone disguised as a police officer, or even an actual police officer. Here are details of the four cases: _In October 1986, Rebecca A. Dowski, 21, a William and Mary student from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Cathleen M. Thomas, 27, a Virginia Beach stockbroker, were found strangled and stabbed in Miss Thomas' car along the parkway. _In September 1987, Robin M. Edwards, 14, of Newport News and David L. Knobling, 20, of Hampton were found shot to death on their first date t Ragged Island Wildlife Refuge in Isle of Wight County. _In April 1988, Keith Call, 20, and Cassandra Hailey, 19, two Christopher Newport College students, disappeared on their first date. Call's pickup truck was found abandoned on the parkway. _In September 1989, Annamaria Phelps, 18, and Lauer, both of Amelia County, disappeared on their way to Virginia Beach. Lauer's car was found at a rest stop on Interstate 64 in New Kent County, and the couple's bodies were discovered in woods nearby six weeks later. Miss Phelps died of a knife wound but the cause of Lauer's death was not determined.

DOC.HEAD: Accident At Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: An accident was reported Sunday at a nuclear power plant south of Barcelona, but a regional official said there had been no radiation leak and the situation was under control. Tarragona civil governor Ramon Sanchez said the accident at the Vandellos II plant was caused by a leak of vaporized water in the primary circuit inside the plant's reactor. He said the reactor had been shut off gradually, and later the plant was disconnected from the national electric network. ``There was no radiation leak at any time,'' Sanchez said. He said the situation was ``completely under control.'' The plant, in Vandellos on the Mediterranean coast 93 miles south of Barcelona, has had a number of accidents since it began operating in 1987. Its sister plant, Vandellos I, was shut down in April due to a serious fire on Oct. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Get Choice for First Time In Chad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with color, voter registration, quote; pickup 4th graf pvs, `The 4,000...'
DOC.TEXT: Voters in war-scarred Chad cast ballots Sunday in the first contested election since independence in 1960, but opposition parties remain banned and virtually all candidates were from the ruling party. Voters chose among 436 pro-government candidates for the 123 seats in a new national assembly. Most were from the ruling National Union for Independence and the Revolution. ``Democracy, here we are!'' declared an enthusiastic commentator on state radio, which reported calm, orderly voting throughout the country. Some polling stations in N'Djamena, the capital, were reported crowded and others nearly deserted as Chad's 3 million eligible voters had their first opportunity to pick among political rivals. Although opposition parties were barred from the elections, the campaign was lively and hard-fought. Candidates toured city streets in vehicles equipped with loudspeakers and wooed voters with offers of low-priced beer or free sugar. In one N'Djamena district, 26 candidates were competing. The 4,000 polling stations spread across the vast, landlocked nation opened at 6 a.m. local time and were scheduled to close at midnight. Final results were not expected for at least two days. The elections are the product of constitutional reforms approved by 99 percent of the electorate in a Dec. 10 referendum that also gave President Hissene Habre another seven-year term. Habre voted about in his N'Djamena neighborhood, then told journalists that Chad was entering ``a phase of democratization.'' ``I hope these processes will be seen through to completion,'' he said. Of the 123 assembly seats, five are reserved for women and will be allocated on a delayed basis if less than five women win seats outright. Assembly members will serve five-year terms. Few senior members of the government or ruling party are seeking seats in the assembly, which will replace the recently dissolved National Consultative Council. The council had served as national legislature since 1982, but its members were appointed by Habre and its powers were limited. Some council members have questioned whether the new assembly will have greater authority. The three-week campaign ended without any reports of serious political violence, although the state-controlled press scolded some candidates for wooing support with gifts or emphasizing clan allegiances rather than issues. Chad has a population of about 5.5 million. It is one of the world's poorest countries, with an annual per capita income of $200, and has been engaged in civil war almost continuously since independence from France three decades ago. Habre's government is locked in a struggle with Libyan-backed rebels who stage raids on border outposts from neighboring Sudan. The only previous legislative elections in Chad were in 1962, but the ruling party put up only one candidate for each seat.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Artificial Heart Recipient Dies At Age 30
DOC.TEXT: Pioneer artificial heart recipient Michael Drummond, who received two artificial hearts and one human heart, has died of multiple organ failure at age 30, five years after his first transplant. Drummond succumbed Saturday night to overwhelming complications including a blood infection, kidney failure and lung problems brought on by a combination of a diseased gallbladder and obesity, said Dr. Jack G. Copeland. Copeland called Drummond ``a pal and a friend and a good patient.'' In 1987, when his first artificial heart was presented to the Smithsonian Institute's National Museum of American History, Drummond said: ``I guess I am sort of a part of history, but not by choice. It's possible 100 years from now that the artificial heart will be as routine as a blood transfusion.'' Drummond and Copeland set medical history in 1985 when Drummond became the youngest of six Jarvik-7 artificial heart recipients and the first to undergo an implant as a bridge to human transplant. On Aug. 29, 1985 he was given his Jarvik-7 after a viral syndrome had caused congestive heart failure and Copeland determined he had only 48 hours to live. After 9{ days on the Jarvik heart, Drummond received the donor heart of a 19-year-old Texas man who died in a motorcycle crash. Drummond recovered fully, including from a minor stroke while on the Jarvik, and led a normal life for 4{ years, resuming work at a Phoenix-area grocery. But he had been on a downhill course since undergoing emergency surgery Feb. 3 to remove a gangrenous gallbladder that led to a severe blood infection, a blood clot in the lungs and an episode of rejection of his artificial heart. Copeland replaced Drummond's failing transplanted heart May 21 with a Symbion J-7-70 artificial heart. Within two days of the second implant other complications developed, including fluid retention in the lungs and kidney impairment. Drummond, 6-foot-2, weighing 268 pounds with an engaging smile that offset a quiet, stoic demeanor, ``certainly had the fight,'' said Lisa Slayton, a member of the cardiothoracic intensive care unit's nursing team. She said the nursing team had had a good cry after his death. ``We all took care of Mike like he was our brother. He was like family.'' Drummond's father, Clarence, said in a wavering voice Saturday night, ``We're just grateful that the artificial heart was here for Mike the first time. He wouldn't have had the 4{ years if he hadn't had (it). ``And even this time, there were still things that Mike wanted to do, and with the artificial heart he had a shot at it, anyway. It didn't work out, but he had a shot at it.''
