DOC.TEXT: Former Lovin' Spoonful member John Sebastian is planning to join singer-songwriter Laura Nyro next month for a benefit to save dolpins. The Aug. 1 concert will help the Dolphin Project, a Florida environmental group. The group is working to eliminate abuse of dolphins in captivity. ``Money from the concert will go toward a sanctuary in the Florida Keys to take abused dolphins and dolphins that have been stranded on the beach and rehabilitate them back to the sea,'' said Janie Coleman, one the benefit's organizers. Sebastian played with the pioneering folk-rock band the Lovin' Spoonful in the 1960s, known for such hits as ``Summer in the City'' and ``Do You Believe in Magic.'' He wrote the music for several films, including, ``What's Up Tiger Lilly?'' ``The Care Bears Movie'' and music for the television show, ``Welcome Back, Kotter.'' Nyro is known for writing such hits as ``And When I Die,'' ``Stoned Soul Picnic'' and ``Eli's Coming.''

DOC.HEAD: Bombings Seen as Emergence of Right-Wing Terrorists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 bgng, `The Sunday...'' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with government saying nine white extremists under detention. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Leaders on...'
DOC.TEXT: A wave of bombings and attacks is widely viewed as the start of a terrorist campaign by right-wing extremists who want to preserve white rule at any price. Government and security officials fear the terrorism will be a major threat to stability as white and black leaders seek a peaceful solution to South Africa's centuries-old racial divisions. The right hopes it can preserve white rule by foiling any peace talks. ``What they are doing is to harm the efforts at reconciliation, as well as the hopes of a peaceful transition to a new society,'' The Citizen newspaper said in an editorial July 5. ``South Africa does not need white terrorists any more than it needs black terrorists.'' Minister of Law and Order Adriaan Vlok said Sunday nine white right-wing whites had been detained without charges in connection with a series of bombings against anti-apartheid targets that began on April 12. Vlok said all nine had been detained under the Internal Security Act, which allows for indefinite detention without trial. ``The people arrested are all supporters of a far-right political ideology, but cannot thus far be connected to any particular organization,'' he said. Leaders on both sides say right-wing attacks could lead to general racial violence and undermine the peace effort. Black leaders say they will be forced to strike back if their people are hurt by the extremists. Some extreme right-wing groups have declared war on President F.W. de Klerk's government for announcing that it wants to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution to share power with blacks. Six bombings in Johannesburg in a week, including an attack July 6 on a black bus station that injured 24 people, are seen as the first major offensive by the right wing. Other attacks in recent months included random killings of blacks and attacks on Jewish temples. The terrorism has come at a time when such black nationalist groups as the African National Congress have all but abandoned violence. Government officials say the right poses a far greater threat than the armed struggle of the ANC and other black organizations. The ANC campaign, which began in 1961, was largely ineffective because of the group's internal problems and the superior strength of South African forces. Terrorism by whites is likely to be much more effective and dangerous, security officials said. Nearly all white men receive compulsory military training. Guns and explosives are readily available to whites and the right has numerous sympathizers in the police and military, they said. It also is much easier for white extremists to operate without suspicion in a society with apartheid laws that give priviliged status to whites. Extremist white groups have taunted the government and police with their ability to operate easily and elude capture. One stole scores of weapons from air force headquarters in Pretoria in April with inside help. ``There is no time to plan a counterrevolution; it is now open war,'' Piet Rudolph, the group's leader, said in a videotape sent to newspapers. ``We will use every means at our disposal to fight the de Klerk government, the overthrow of which is the highest priority to us.'' Rudolph has claimed responsibility for bombing two offices of de Klerk's National Party. An organization calling itself the White Wolves has claimed responsibility for attacks in Johannesburg. Police have not broken any of the extremist underground groups that have claimed responsibility for bombings and other attacks. Officials believe the extreme right consists of only a few hundred people, but security officials say even a handful of white terrorists could cause havoc. South African press reports say up to 45 extreme-right groups operate in South Africa. Conservatives contend de Klerk has no right to end apartheid, and they demand creation of a state for whites only. Several large right-wing political groups have been forming private armies. The Afrikaner Resistance Movement and similar groups deny responsibility for the terrorism, but regularly display their well-armed ``commandos'' or military units. Leaders of the right claim South Africa is rushing toward a race war and that thousands of whites are flocking to their movement. ``It will be a holy war,'' Afrikaner Resistance leader Eugene TerreBlanche said at a recent display of men in Nazi-style uniforms. ``We know we are heading for a confrontation.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Premier to Oversee Early Talks with Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov will head a commission to prepare negotiations with Lithuania on granting the Baltic republic independence, a Lithuanian government spokesman said Sunday. Czeslovas Jurshenas, a spokesman for Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene and a deputy to the Lithuanian Parliament, said Lithuania was preparing documents to present at preliminary talks to set up formal negotiations on the republic's quest to separate from the Soviet Union. Prunskiene told Lithuanian TV viewers on Saturday that she had spoken by telephone with Ryzhkov. She said he had shown understanding for three major demands that Lithuania had for the period leading to formal negotiations, Jurshenas said. The spokesman said in a telephone interview that Lithuania wants Moscow to suspend draft requirements for Lithuanians into the Soviet army, although any Lithuanian who wanted to join was free to do so. The Baltic republic is also demanding that the Soviet Union permit normal contact with the outside world, lift travel restrictions at the one border crossing with Poland and consider opening a second one, he said. Finally, Vilnius wants Moscow to ease the restrictions it imposed on foreign travelers, especially officials, after Lithuania declared its independence on March 11, he said. Jurshenas also said that Vilnius would like a pledge from Moscow that the Soviet Union will not interfere with Lithuania's efforts to establish direct contacts with other Soviet republics. Lithuania had been seeking to get supplies from other Soviet republics without Moscow's authorization after a blockade was imposed on almost all oil, most natural gas and numerous other items on April 18. But the Lithuanian Supreme Council, or parliament, on June 29 accepted a compromise which traded a 100-day moratorium on the declaration of independence for an immediate end to the blockade and the start of negotiations. Jurshenas said preliminary talks could start within 10 days. Lithuania, an independent nation between the two World Wars, was forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union by dictator Josef Stalin in 1940 along with neighboring Latvia and Estonia. Those republics are also seeking to secede from the Soviet Union, but they have proceeded at a slower pace than Lithuania in breaking with Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Stefan Edberg Defeats Boris Becker for Wimbledon Championship
DOC.TEXT: Sweden's Stefan Edberg beat Boris Becker of West Germany in a five-set epic Sunday to capture his second men's tennis championship at Wimbledon. A service winner completed an the final on Centre Court, which ended 6-2, 6-2, 3-6, 3-6, 6-4. Edberg came back from a 1-3 deficit in the final set to win. It was the first five-set men's championship at Wimbledon since Jimmy Connors beat fellow American John McEnroe 3-6, 6-3, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4 in 1982. This was the third consecutive meeting between the two stars for the Wimbledon championship. Becker, the defending champion, was playing for his fourth title in six years. Edberg won the title two years ago. In the first two sets, completed in less than an hour, Edberg looked invincible and Becker nearly invisible. But Becker would not give up easily, picking up his game and taking the momentum in the third and fourth sets. It was only the second time in his career that Becker has come back from two sets down to tie a match, then lose. The last time was also to Edberg in the French Open semifinals last year. Edberg won 6-3, 6-4, 5-7, 3-6, 6-2. As the Swede won Wimbledon for the second time in three years, he thrust his fists in the air and smiled broadly. He and Becker embraced at the net, then Edberg took off his shirt and heaved it into the stands. Becker sat on his chair, looking stunned. He said later if he had just been able to extend his 3-1 lead in the final set, ``It would be a different story.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Says Aid to Cuba Will ``Fade Away''
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official said Sunday his nation will gradually end the financial aid to Cuba that the Bush administration says must stop before Moscow gets any U.S. economic support. Gennadi Gerasimov, spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, said on CBS' ``Face the Nation'' that subsidies for Fidel Castro's Marxist government will ``fade away, but not tomorrow.'' Gerasimov, speaking from Moscow, did not elaborate on plans for the aid, which he called a ``hidden subsidy'' based mainly on paying higher than market prices for Cuban sugar and giving Havana a break on its purchases of Soviet oil. ``This is the hidden subsidy, not just cash,'' he said. ``This is our obligation.'' Other senior Soviet officials have said in recent weeks that aid to foreign nations, including Cuba, would be reassessed, although Moscow has not made an explicit public commitment to any reductions. The question of Western financial assistance to Moscow is expected to be a major subject of debate at the seven-nation economic summit that opens in Houston on Monday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, interviewed Sunday in Houston on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' said the Soviet-Cuba situation was one reason President Bush is unwilling to provide direct aid to Moscow. ``We still have major problems with Soviet assistance to Cuba,'' Baker said. He added, however, that the administration saw indications that internal Soviet economic pressures eventually would force a cut in aid to communist nations. ``The Soviets know they are going to have to start pulling back,'' he said. Baker said Moscow spends about $15 billion a year in support of Third World communist countries.

DOC.HEAD: East German Communists Linked With Terrorists
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's deposed Communist leadership maintained links with any known terrorist group that would help destabilize Western nations, the country's interior minister said in an interview released Sunday. Before their ouster last fall, the Communist leaders were willing to deal with ``all terrorist groups known to us,'' Peter-Michael Diestel told the West German newspaper Die Welt. Specifically, the now-disbanded Ministry for State Security, or Stasi as it is known in German, ``maintained at least informal contacts'' with the Basque separatist group ETA and the Irish Republican Army, which seeks to overthrow British rule over Northern Ireland, Diestel said. Die Welt's interview with the conservative politician was to be published in its Monday edition. An advance text was made available by the paper on Sunday. Diestel spoke after the recent arrests in East Germany of eight alleged Red Army Faction terrorists wanted for attacks in West Germany. The eight had reportedly been given new identities and sanctuary by the Stasi, possibly with the knowledge of former Communist Party chief Erich Honecker and Stasi head Erich Mielke. One of the Red Army Faction suspects, Susanne Albrecht, gave herself up to West German police and reportedly promised to speak out on the group's structure and earlier terrorist attacks. Diestel, who promised further disclosures on East Germany's former links with international terrorism next week, said, ``We have arrested more people than you are aware of.'' He refused to specify whether those were also Red Army Faction members, or whether any of the detainees were still being held. But he did say that in some cases, East Germany's statute of limitations meant suspects had to be released, while in others there was insufficient proof. Speaking of the former government, Diestel said that ``nothing was too dirty for them in their political deliberations.'' ``We hope very much that these weren't contacts aimed at aiding and abetting international terrorism,'' he said. The hard-line Communist regime was ousted in a peaceful popular revolution late last year.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorm Damage In Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorms battered Minnesota on Sunday, while rain also was scattered from the Southwest to the Midwest and over the Southeast, and temperatures were high across much of the nation. Thunderstorms generating wind up to 70 mph damaged buildings, uprooted trees, knocked down power lines and flattened fields around Minnesota but no injuries were reported. Don Stob, deputy sheriff in Mille Lacs County, said the worst damage in the county was reported by a farmer about 3 miles southeast of Milaca, north of Minneapolis and about 33 miles northeast of St. Cloud. ``He had 13 trees down in his yard, a power line down, the roof off his corn crib and some shingles off his barn. And one of his hay fields was flattened,'' Stob said. Trees were uprooted and power lines torn down all around Minneapolis, said Mike McCosky, a foreman with the city streets department. But no major thoroughfares were blocked, he said. Northern States Power Co. spokesman Sam Macalus said the storm left more than 60,000 customers in the metropolitan area without power. In southwestern Minnesota, strong wind knocked down trees and power lines in Tracy, leaving much of the town without power. Trees and power lines also were reported down in nearby Balaton and Garvin. By afternoon, showers and thunderstorms were scattered across west-central through northeastern Wisconsin and into northern and central Michigan. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered from southeastern South Dakota across western Nebraska, across southeastern Wyoming, eastern and central Colorado, parts of New Mexico, northern and central Arizona, south-central Utah and south-central Texas. In the Southeast, showers and thunderstorms were scattered over southeastern Louisiana, central Alabama, southern and central Florida, the North Carolina coast and southeastern Virginia. East-central Pennsylvania also got rain. Heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.43 inches at Pellston, Mich. Well to the north, strong thunderstorms produced wind gusts of almost 65 mph during the night at Fairbanks, Alaska, marking the eastern edge of cooler temperatures and possibly breaking that area's heat wave. Temperatures had reached 80 degrees or higher on the previous nine days. Temperatures were high over much of the nation, including an early reading of 100 degrees at Nashville, Tenn. Temperatures rose the 90s as far north as Indiana, southern Wisconsin, southern Iowa and southeastern Nebraska. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 37 at both Truckee, Calif., and West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 56 at Laramie, Wyo., to 101 at Nashville.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Escalates Involvement in Bolivian Drug War
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is setting up a sophisticated intelligence-gathering system in Bolivia to keep tabs on drug traffickers, and it has sent in advisers to help, a U.S. official said. Increased U.S. military presence in Bolivia is part of an intensification of the anti-drug war, encouraged by promises of aid from Washington. Eugene Castillo, acting U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration attache for Bolivia, said Friday the U.S. Southern Military Command would ``reinforce the Bolivian police and DEA operational capabilities throughout South America.'' Bolivia, an impoverished South American country of 7 million people, produces one-third of the cocaine for U.S. and other foreign markets. Castillo described the new system as ``innovative.'' ``It gives us ... intelligence and the ability to transmit that intellingence to affected areas so that operations can be planned and mounted in a minimum amount of time,'' Castillo said. Castillo spoke Friday on condition the story would not be used until Sunday. A computer system, recently installed in La Paz and Santa Cruz, will link major cocaine centers and provide data on trafficking. It will also provide a safe way of transmiting information among anti-drug operations centers. It will shortly be installed in three other Bolivian cocaine centers. Currently, the DEA and Bolivian police rely on Korean-war-vintage radio equipment that can easily be intercepted by drug traffickers, who use the latest in radio communications equipment. Castillo said the U.S. Military Command is also helping the DEA and Bolivian police ``formulate and maintain a country-wide operational strategy'' to prevent the production and export of drugs and import of chemicals. For about a month, three military advisers _ one each from the U.S. Navy, Army and Air Force _ have been coordinating strategy with Bolivian police and the DEA. At least 10 other special agents are training Bolivian anti-drug police. The U.S. military is prohibited by the Bolivian and U.S. governments from directly participating in any anti-drug operations. ``The military is only a support force,''' Castillo said. ``All we are doing is using military expertise to assist us in intelligence gathering.'' During a May meeting in Washington, Bolivian leader Jaime Paz Zamora and President Bush agreed on greater military involvement in the anti-drug war. Paz Zamora agreed to commit 900 soldiers to the effort and to increase air force and navy involvement. Bolivian military personnel are already assisting police in anti-drug activities. In return, Bolivia was promised $75 million worth of military equipment and training for 1990-1991. But the growing militarization of the anti-drug war has created opposition in Bolivia and raised concern that a largely peaceful police enforcement effort could escalate into civil wars such those in Peru and Colombia. ``The participation of the military in coca-producing zones ... is only producing violence,'' said Felipe Caceres Garcia, a leader of the coca growers association of Chapare. The region the size of New Jersey produces 80 percent of Bolivian coca leaves, the base for cocaine. ``In Bolivia, there is no violence, there is no terrorism and we do not want it to get to that,'' Caceres Garcia said. Bolivia's army is better known for coups d'etat and corruption than combat skills. A military government that took power in 1980 worked closely with cocaine traffickers. The army also has a reputation for heavy-handedness. When it is called in to put down strikes, for instance, bloodshed often results. Coca-growing peasants, militant and well organized, have sworn they will resist any any military crackdown. But those who favor military involvement, including U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard, say army action is needed if ``Bolivia is going to nip in the bud what is developing into a real national threat.'' ``Many Bolivians remember the regime of Luis Garcia Meza in the early 80s and the instability of the country's democratic institutions before that and are afraid of a return to those problems,'' Gelbard said Friday, also on condition the story not be used until Sunday. ``We believe that the broad-based public support of democracy in Bolivia and the military's clear commitment to democratic principals poses no threat.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO CORRECT CODING
Former SS Soldier Returns To Politics, Neo-Nazi Held
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's ultra-rightist Republican Party on Sunday re-elected a former Waffen SS soldier to be its chairman, ending a six-week fight over the group's leadership. East Germany, meanwhile, briefly detained the self-proclaimed ``fuehrer'' _ German for leader _ of a group that openly advocates Nazi ideology. The re-election of Franz Schoenhuber and the arrest of Michael Kuehnen came amid reports of growing activity, particulary in East Germany, of rightist and neo-Nazi groups. West Germany has long had a small but vocal neo-Nazi movement. Ultra-conservative organizations like Schoenhuber's have sought to capitalize on economic insecurity and resentment of the country's immigrant population. In East Germany, the ousted Communist leadership regarded neo-Nazism as a problem afflicting only its capitalist Western neighbor. But groups of ultra-rightist East German youths wearing swastikas and giving Nazi salutes have attacked rival gangs, and there have also been reports of vandalism attacks on Jewish graves and property. Along with Jean-Marie le Pen in France, Schoenhuber is one of Western Europe's most notorious ultra-rightist politicians. At a tumultuous two-day conference, 376 of 563 Republican delegates voted for Schoenhuber, who resigned as chairman in mid-May after criticizing the party for drifting too far right. Dozens of police sealed off the conference hall in this eastern Bavarian town as delegates cheered Schoenhuber and booed his main rivals, Harald Neubauer and Franz Glasauer. In his acceptance speech, Schoenhuber said the Republicans under his leadership would be ``a party of historically purged patriotism ... right-wing, therefore.'' East Germany banned the Republicans from taking part in the nation's first free elections last March, and Schoenhuber himself has been refused entry to East Germany several times. The Republicans also adopted a motion banning members of several neo-Nazi groups from holding office in the party. The motion was put forward by Schoenhuber, reflecting his publicly expressed concern that the group will be become identified with neo-Nazism. Late Saturday, the East German Interior Ministry reported it had arrested Kuehnen, a former lieutenant in the West German Army, who has twice served prison sentences for his neo-Nazi activities. Kuehnen, who calls himself a ``fuehrer,'' is West Germany's most notorious neo-Nazi. He was detained during a rally near the East German city of Cottbus and released a short time later, according to the East German news agency ADN. He has been charged with propagating ``fascist, militarist'' ideas during a May 1 demonstration by his group near Erfurt, East Germany, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Says Husband Warned of Blast, Identifications Continue
DOC.TEXT: The widow of a millwright killed in an explosion at the ARCO Chemical Co. said her husband called her half an hour before the blast, saying workers restarting equipment there were afraid it might explode. Lori Davis, 26, said her husband, Michael, had been working an extended shift at the plant Thursday for Austin Industrial Inc., a subcontractor at ARCO Chemical. Davis, 24, called home about 11:15 p.m., she said. ``Michael told me they were about to start a compressor that they had fixed. But they were afraid to do it because they thought it might blow,'' Mrs. Davis recalled Saturday. Davis died in a blast minutes later along with 16 others, including employees from Austin Industrial, ARCO Chemical employees and Waste Processors Industries Inc. The Occupational Safety and Health Organization and other ivestigators continued searching Sunday for a cause of the blast, said Gerald Davis, ACRO Chemical spokesman. Harold Sorgenti, president and chief executive officer of ARCO Chemical, said workers had been repairing an electric compressor near a 900,000-gallon wastewater treatment tank when the explosion occurred. The tank separates hydrocarbons from water and then a compressor pumps the sometimes volatile vapors into a pipeline where impurities can be removed before releasing the gases to the atmosphere, officials said. Mrs. Davis, who married June 9, said her husband phoned her three times last Thursday to say he was working late. She said employees had been working long hours in recent weeks because the plant was shorthanded. `I don't think that work hours had anything to do with this,'' said Earl McCaleb, plant manager. ``It's not all that uncommon to work 16-hour shifts throughout the industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Nine White Extremists Arrested in South Africa
With AM-SAfrica-Extremists
DOC.TEXT: Nine white extremists have been detained in connection with a series of bombings aimed at anti-apartheid targets, an official said Sunday. Adriaan Vlok, the minister of law and order, said all nine men had been detained under the Internal Security Act, which allows for indefinite detention without trial. They have not been charged. ``The people arrested are all supporters of a far-right political ideology, but cannot thus far be connected to any particular organization,'' Vlok said. He identified three of those arrested as Leonard Veenendaal, Darryl Stopforth and David Rootenberg. He said the other six men could not yet be named because of the nature of the investigation, but he did not elaborate. Vlok did not say when the arrests were made. Since April 12, there have been a series of bombings in which right-wingers were suspected. The most serious attack was the Friday bombing of a taxi stand in which 27 blacks were injured. Among the targets in the bombings were two offices of the National Party. That party leads the country's white government. Right-wing whites have expressed outrage at President F.W. de Klerk's plans to end apartheid _ South Africa's system of racial discrimination _ and share power with the 30-million black majority. Both de Klerk and the African National Congress, the leading black opposition group, have said a terrorist campaign by heavily armed right-wing whites could undermine black-white negotiations. Veenendaal and Stopforth were arrested last year in neighboring Namibia and charged with killing a security guard at a U.N. office. Veenendaal and Stopforth escaped from Namibia in December and returned to South Africa. South Africa granted independence to Namibia on March 21, a move opposed by right-wingers. The United Nations supervised the transition to independence. Also Sunday, the independent South African Press Association reported that the pro-apartheid Conservative Party said it plans to defy a government law requiring public facilities to open to all races by October. The Separate Amenities Act, passed in 1953, gave local governments and privately-owned enterprises the right to reserve facilities for whites, such as parks, hotels, swimming pools, bathrooms and recreation centers. In a statement after Saturday's Conservative Party meeting, Pikkie Coetzee, a member of Parliament and chairman of the party's municipal committee, said the Conservative Party ``also warns the government very seriously that the friction which will come from its discontinuation of the Separate Amenities Act will be the exclusive responsibility of the government.'' The Conservative Party won 31 percent of the vote in September's election. It is the official opposition in the white chamber of Parliament, and the Conservatives control dozens of local councils throughout the country.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers' Group Stops Challenges to its Abortion Rights Position
DOC.TEXT: The National Education Association soundly defeated all challenges to its abortion rights position as it concluded a four-day convention Sunday. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos sent his ``warmest greetings'' to the convention and pledged to work closely with the union to improve schools. The message seemed to signal an end to a feud between the NEA and the Education Department that began during the Reagan administration when the department was led by the outspoken William Bennett, now drug czar. Although reluctant to use the word ``abortion,'' a majority of the 8,100 delegates Sunday defeated an attempt to change the union's support of family planning, ``including the right to reproductive freedom.'' The nation's largest teachers' union also voted to oppose any legislation that erodes the Supreme Court's abortion ruling or tries to impede access to information on ``choice of reproductive health care options.'' ``Whether you or I agree with abortion is irrelevant,'' said Robert Chase, a vice president of the nation's largest teachers' union, during floor debate. ``What is relevant is the right of women to make the choice for themselves.'' Robert Pawson, head of Teachers Saving Children, vowed to continue attempts to ``reform the NEA from within.'' Pawson said abortion opponents for the first time in 10 years had been able to get NEA delegates to act on the issue. In the past, he said abortion rights advocates had prevented debate on the issue. In the daylong session, Kathleen Holzmeister of the Illinois Education Association lost an effort to forbid abortion counseling at community-operated, school-based family planning clinics. On Saturday, delegates easily defeated an attempt to stop the union's policy of lobbying for abortion rights. Christine Nowak of New York led efforts to eliminate abortion lobbying from the legislative agenda of the nation's largest teachers' union. She and others argued that union dues should not be used for such activity because the NEA's 2 million members have a variety of views on the issue. In a resounding voice vote, the legislative amendment was rejected. In other action, the union put itself on record in support of giving teachers more authority over their jobs and school curriculums _ popularly called site-based decision-making. The NEA also agreed to write President Bush and Congress in support of sanctions against South Africa until apartheid is eliminated, and to encourage pension funds' divestment of companies doing business in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Library to Screen Researchers, Papers
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon's presidential library will pick and choose who can do research there and probably will keep out Pulitzer Prize-winning Watergate reporter Bob Woodward, library officials say. The library also will lack a full set of memos, letters and other documents from Nixon's White House years when it opens later this month. That's because the originals are in the custody of the government, and Nixon has chosen to copy only those he considers important to the library. The actions have irked some scholars who say they mistrust a library where documents will be screened. ``Who knows what the Nixon people have screened out?'' said Stanley Kutler, a Wisconsin history professor who recently published a book on the Watergate scandal that led to Nixon's resignation as president on Aug. 19, 1974. The library's director, Hugh Hewitt, says every document of any importance, including many relating to Watergate, will be in the library. But he acknowledged that Woodward probably wouldn't be allowed to study them. ``I don't think we'd ever open the doors to Bob Woodward, he's not a responsible journalist,'' Hewitt said. ``It would be far more of a taint to let the premises be used indiscriminately by groups who oppose everything he (Nixon) has worked for,'' he added. Woodward and fellow reporter Washington Post reporter Carl Bernstein uncovered the White House coverup of the botched burglary of Democratic National Headquarters in the Watergate complex in 1972. Woodward, the Post's assistant managing editor for investigations, said the suggestion that he or others would be kept out ``demonstrates that the library will be part of a continuing cover-up.'' The Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library will be able to use its autonomy as a privately run facility to choose the scholars it allows to do research. Of the nation's other presidential libraries, only the Rutherford B. Hayes library is privately operated. Eight are run by the National Archives, which will also control the Ronald Reagan library under construction in Simi Valley. The Nixon library's exhibition section will be dedicated July 19 at a ceremony to be attended by President Bush and former Presidents Reagan and Gerald Ford. The archives will open sometime next year. Hewitt said the library will include a ``Watergate Hall'' and many documents detailing the scandal, including the 1972 ``smoking gun'' tape recording in which Nixon says he will ask the CIA and FBI to halt the Watergate investigation. Excerpts will be played for visitors. That's not enough to satisfy Kutler, who accused Nixon of being obsessed with secrecy and control. The idea that Nixon wants to control the library's contents is ``a presumption on the part of the liberal Nixon haters, '' said Walter Annenberg, Nixon's ambassador to Great Britain. ``That library is going to contain everything, favorable or unfavorable,'' said William E. Simon, president of the library foundation. ``Academics and historians have always hated Nixon.''

DOC.HEAD: Health and Safety Plan for Crack Cocaine Houses Reconsidered
DOC.TEXT: A regulation attacking crack cocaine houses by requiring them to have health and safety plans appears likely to be replaced with one declaring them health hazards. ``The prosecutor was concerned that it looked like we were permitting an illegal operation,'' said Chuck Kleeburg, King County director of environmental health. the county prosecutor's office proposes replacing the existing regulation with one designating crack houses a health hazard because of addiction, toxic exposure and violence. Health officials could fine landlords and tenants $1,000 for each day a crack house remained in operation. The Board of Health is scheduled to vote on the new plan July 24. The original regulation, which was adopted in January and scheduled to take effect July 1, county police were to inform health officials when a building was being used for making or selling the potent crack form of cocaine. The owner then was to be notified of an apparent violation of health regulations, given 10 days to present a plan for reducing the health and safety risk and ordered to pay a $100 review fee. Health officials said they never expected to get a health and safety plan and would use fines for failing to file health and safety plans as another way to attack crack houses. Police have relied heavily on a state law allowing civil abatement fe proceedings to close and condemn crack houses after owners fail to end drug operations. The statute has been used less frequently by police in the county and suburban jurisdictions.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Mass Killer Goes On Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th and 6th grafs to CORRECT spelling to Angelia sted Angela
DOC.TEXT: A winery worker is set to go on trial Monday on charges he slaughtered his wife, two daughters and four others in a murderous rampage, but the case may be delayed for two months. Ramon Salcido's lawyer, Marteen Miller, said he would ask visiting San Mateo Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell to reset the trial for September. Miller claims his client was illegally extradited from Mexico a few days after the April 1989 slayings. Miller said he would argue that Salcido, charged with seven counts of murder, had a brain dysfunction that fueled the bloody killing spree in the Sonoma County vineyard country, 35 miles north of San Francisco. The trial was moved to San Mateo County, south of San Francisco, in response to a venue change request by Miller, the public defender for Sonoma County. Investigators said Salcido was enraged by what he believed were infidelities by his wife, Angelia. He said he believed he was not the father of their eldest daughter, Sofia. Three days before the rampage, the marriage had been strained when Salcido was served with court papers ordering him to pay child support to his ex-wife in Fresno County, whom Angelia knew nothing about. In a statement to a sheriff returning with him from Mexico City, Salcido said the killing started after bouts of cocaine and alcohol use. According to his statement, Salcido took his three daughters, Theresa, 1, Sofia, 4, and Carmina, 3, to a county dump site where he slit their throats; Carmina survived. He then drove to the home of Robert Richards Sr. and his family, Salcido's in-laws. He knocked his mother-in-law, Marian Louise Richards, 47, unconscious and then killed her daughters, 12-year-old Ruth, and 8-year-old Marie. Before leaving, he allegedly stabbed his mother-in-law to death as she regained consciousness. Salcido said he went back to his Boyes Hot Springs home where he beat his wife and shot her with a .22-caliber pistol as she tried to get to a telephone. Salcido said he thought about killing himself, but decided to go to the Grand Cru Winery, where he worked, to shoot co-workers Tracey Toovey, 35, and Ken Butti, 33. ``I've killed already so many, I think I'll kill ... the two other guys,'' the detective quoted Salcido as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Charles Taylor Has Gone From College Activist To Rebel Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `Taylor was...' to CORRECT that two of Taylor's brothers and three sisters live in Rhode Island
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Liberia
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: While Charles Taylor was driving rebel forces against the president of Liberia, his wife was driving their children to summer camp and trying to rally support for her husband's rebellion. Tupee Taylor hasn't seen her husband for five years. But she is unflinching in her belief that her husband will overthrow Liberia's President Samuel Doe. The rebels accuse Doe, who gained power of the tiny West African country in a bloody coup in 1980, of corruption, tribalism, and brutal suppression of the opposition. Taylor, 42, and his forces invaded the West African country from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Mrs. Taylor learned of the action when her husband telephoned on New Year's Day. ``I wasn't surprised or shocked,'' she said. ``Someone had to do something. And if anyone would do it I know Charles would be the one. He's very determined and very, very intelligent.'' Taylor's forces have continued to tighten their noose on the capital of Monrovia. Rebels besieging the capital rejected a cease-fire proposed by Doe and resumed fighting Sunday, rebel sources said. Doe continued to decline an American offer of safe passage out of the country. And 5,500 miles away, Mrs. Taylor, 29, worked to promote her husband's cause while trying to maintain a normal life for her school-age children. ``The best I can do is to get as much publicity as I can,'' she said. ``I am a Christian and I pray a lot. We don't want to be separated. But it's safer for us here.'' The Taylors met in the United States through their involvement with Liberian student associations. She attended Seton Hall while he graduated from Bentley College with an economics degree. ``He always had political ambitions,'' she said. ``He was always outspoken. He always spoke out about the injustices in Liberia and the need for democracy. If he is the next leader of Liberia, we'll have a better future. Things will be different.'' The Taylors married in Liberia in 1980 and witnessed the coup that overthrew the late President William Tolbert. ``We stayed because that's our country and no matter who came into power we believed in staying there and restoring democracy,'' Mrs. Taylor said. Taylor took a job in Doe's cabinet as director of the General Services Agency, but became disillusioned and was arrested for circulating subversive materials in 1981. He continued working for Doe's government until 1982, when their house was ransacked and he was implicated in the first of many coup attempts, she said. The Taylors returned to the United States, where Taylor was arrested in May 1984 outside Boston and accused of embezzling $1 million from Liberia, a charge his wife claims Doe fabricated. Sixteen months later, Taylor fled the Plymouth County House of Corrections in Massachusetts while awaiting extradition. Mrs. Taylor said she does not know how he escaped. ``I was happy he left,'' she said. ``I didn't ask him how he did it.'' She also said she does not know what her husband did in the 4{ years between his escape and the start of the revolution. ``There are so many things Charles could have been doing in that process. Nobody knows,'' she said. Taylor was raised in an affluent family in Althington, Liberia, one of 10 children. Their father was a commissioner of immigration and later became a judge, said Nelson Taylor, one of two Taylor brothers and three sisters living in Rhode Island. The Taylors' two American-born children, Charen, 9, and Camille, 7, learned of their father's activities accidentally. ``I tried to keep it from them because I didn't want to confuse them,'' Mrs. Taylor said. But Charen read about the rebellion in the newspaper and ``so they decided themselves ... and they just started watching the news.'' The United States and other countries have questioned Taylor's commitment to democracy and free elections. His credibility has also been damaged by reports of executions of suspected Doe supporters. Those reports are ``completely false,'' his wife said. ``It makes you crazy because things get distorted,'' Mrs. Taylor said. She said her husband is committed to holding free elections. ``If the Liberians wants Charles Taylor as the leader the Liberian people will vote for Charles Taylor. For right now, he's a fighter,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Suffers Fatal Heart Attack While Leading Singing At Friend's Funeral
DOC.TEXT: A 66-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack while leading the singing at the funeral of a friend. Charles H. Sanford Sr. of Pumpkin Center collapsed Saturday afternoon during the funeral service for Dee Melson at Elliott Funeral Home chapel. He died a short time later. Lawrence County Coronor Harvey Elliott, who owns the funeral home, said a minister had finished speaking and Sanford had gotten up to lead he congregation in a final song when he was stricken. ``I was watching him,'' Elliott said. ``He looked up and then staggered a little bit. I got hold of him and got him out of the chapel into the hall. I knew it was a desperate situation and hollered for somebody to call 911.'' A doctor and registered nurse attending the funeral administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation to Sanford while awaiting an ambulance. He was taken to Lawrence County Hospital where he died. Sanford was retired from Monsanto Chemical Co. in Decatur and was involved in church work, gardening and following his passion for singing, said his son, Charles Jr. ``That was one of the things he loved to do the most,'' the younger Sanford said. ``He was not a professional singer, but he had a good voice and people liked to hear him.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helped Ex-Nazis Enter Canada, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials helped at least 39 people, including ex-Nazis, slip into Canada to build a new life in the early 1950s to reward them for their work as spies, previously classified documents indicate. A study by Ottawa historian Alti Rodal, completed three years ago for a federal royal commission that investigated suspected Nazi war criminals, says the 39 people came to Canada with false documents and identities from U.S. authorities. Ms. Rodal's report was released in heavily censored form in 1987, with several general references to the involvement by U.S. intelligence officers in resettling alleged ex-Nazis. The report said the U.S. officials, who were responsible for screening Europeans seeking a new life in North America after the war, misled Canadian authorities about the backgrounds of some of the emigrants. The 39 cases involved mostly Germans who had worked for Nazi organizations during World War II. They were recruited by the United States after 1945 as part of an intelligence ring to spy on the Russian zone of occupied Germany and suspected Communist sympathizers in the American zone. More details of the resettlement plan emerged last week, as material previously deleted from Ms. Rodal's report was made public following requests by journalists under the Access to Information Act. There was no CIA spokesperson available Sunday in Washington to comment on the new details from Ms. Rodal's report. Government documents cited by Ms. Rodal show the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the External Affairs Department were surprised when they stumbled on the U.S. plan in 1953-54. Lester Pearson, then external affairs minister and future Liberal prime minister, complained the Americans should have taken such people into their own country if they wanted them, rather than dumping them on others. Canadian diplomats in Washington were instructed to take the matter up directly with Allen Dulles, then head of the CIA. Washington eventually provided background information on the people involved and assured External Affairs the information package was complete. But Royal Police memos indicate the police force was skeptical and thought others may have been smuggled in and never detected. One memo from September 1954 noted 35 cases had been discussed at that point with the Americans, but ``we are not convinced that the figures which have been given to us in the first instance are in fact correct.'' Another memo the same month noted four more cases had been discovered. All involved people were sponsored by the U.S. Army Research and Resettlement Branch, which played a key role in relocating former intelligence agents, including Nazi collaborators. Ms. Rodal concluded the Americans probably acted with the knowledge and co-operation of a Royal Police sergeant then stationed in Karlsruhe, West Germany. He apparently kept the scheme from his superior. At least some had criminal records on grounds of moral turpitude _ the immigration category then used to exclude suspected war criminals and Nazi collaborators. The 1985-87 royal commission under Justice Jules Deschenes recommended urgent action against 20 suspected war criminals in Canada and further investigation of 200 other cases. The Justice Department has since initiated three criminal prosecutions and one civil action. It has 45 other cases under consideration.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit-Rdp,Bjt
Briefing For Gorbachev?
DOC.TEXT: Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Sunday that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev should be given a special briefing on the results of the economic summit of industrialized nations. A senior Canadian official, demanding anonymity, said Mulroney suggested that President Bush, as the host of the gathering, provide the Kremlin leader with details of the high-level talks. The briefing could be done by telephone or letter or through an emissary, he said. The summit leaders, he said, should ``send a positive economic signal to the Soviet Union which would match the positive political-military message that came from the London summit of NATO allies.'' The leaders of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization decided on Friday to reshape the Western military alliance in response to the political upheavals in Eastern Europe. They also agreed to invite Gorbachev to speak at the alliance's headquarters in Brussels.
DOC.HEAD: Melting Ice at the Summit
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists had a cool idea for a symbolic, publicity-grabbing gimmick to illustrate their concerns about global warming: A gigantic block of melting ice. Neat. Just the way to grab attention at the economic summit in sweltering Houston. One problem. It turned into a puddle twice as fast as expected. Houston ice carver Nathan Smith worked all night on 10,240 pounds of ice in a downtown park to make a globe showing all the continents, surrounded by the flags of the summit participants. The final piece was carved at about 8:45 a.m. Less than 8 hours later, the ice was virtually gone as mid-afternoon temperatures reached 90 degrees. ``Our climate is heating up; our natural resource base is melting down,'' was the message, according to Wilderness Society President George Frampton. Catherine Moore of the ``Envirosummit'' coalition said organizers though the ice would last until Tuesday, but they miscalculated because the sculptor had never done such a project in heat.

DOC.HEAD: Rally For Young Mother Jailed 121 Days For Refusing To Give Up Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS top 4 grafs to move up reference to woman being permitted to speak to supporters, DELETE implication that demonstration could have led to her release; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``The demonstrators...
DOC.TEXT: About 30 friends and relatives of a Cheyenne Indian mother jailed in a custody dispute with her ex-husband demonstrated outside the jail, and she was briefly led outside to speak to her supporters. Tina Cady has been jailed four months for refusing to return her two small children to their father, who has legal custody, claiming she fears possible child abuse. The youngsters are on an Indian reservation, where state courts can't touch them. Sheriff's deputies took Cady out to speak to the crowd that gathered at the jail Saturday, demanding her release. ``I really appreciate your support, and I'm sure my kids do, too,'' she said. The demonstrators included Tom Gardner Sr. of Lame Deer, who served eight years as a judge on the tribal court of the nearby Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation. Cady is a member of the tribe and lives on the reservation in Lame Deer. Cady, 26, has been jailed since March 9, when state District Judge Joe Hegel held her in contempt for refusing to comply with a court order to return her children to her former husband, Walt Donges, 34, of Colstrip. Donges was awarded custody of the children, 4-year-old Brittany and 2-year-old Ryan, when the couple divorced last October. Cady said that on Feb. 9, when she picked up the children for a visit, she noticed a large bruise on Brittany's buttock. An Indian Health Service doctor examined the bruise and recommended that Cady not return the children to Donges until an investigation had been conducted. Donges has denied causing the bruise or ever hitting his children, contending that the girl was bruised because her little brother bit her. The custody battle reached an impasse when Cady took the children to her parents' home in Busby on the reservation, where they have remained. The reservation is outside the state court's jurisdiction. Last month, the Northern Cheyenne Tribal Court ordered that the children would be temporary wards of that court and placed responsibility for their care with the tribe's social services department. Because of that court action, Cady said that even if she wanted to she could not return Brittany and Ryan to their father. Hegel said in a telephone interview with the Billings Gazette that he doesn't know if Cady's interpretation of the matter is correct, but said he is looking for a quick resolution to the situation.

DOC.HEAD: Warplanes Blast Hezbollah Stronghold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Hezbollah firing missiles at border to retaliate for Israeli air strike, fighting between Palestinian fundamentalists and Sunni Moslem militia in Sidon. No pickup. ^By EDMOND SHEDID
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lebanon-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted a major stronghold of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah in south Lebanon Sunday in their second attack on Lebanon-based guerrillas in three days. Police said at least two people were killed and seven wounded in the attack, which followed reports that kidnappers linked to the Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God, might release one of 16 Western hostages they hold. In Israel, the military command confirmed the raid. It said in a communique: ``The target was destroyed and all planes returned safely to base.'' It gave no other details. Eight hours after the Israeli air attack, Hezbollah guerrillas fired three surface-to-surface missiles from the foothills of Mount Hermon at the Israeli border with Lebanon, police said. The rockets exploded but there was no immediate word of damage or casualties. Israeli border gunners struck back with a long-range artillery barrage targeted on the south Lebanese village of Ein Atta, where the missiles were fired from, police said. It was not immediately clear if the anticipated hostage release would be canceled in retaliation for the Israeli air attack. Moslem fundamentalists claim Western support of Israel encourages its attacks on Lebanon. Police and witnesses in the market town of Nabatiyeh said four Israeli jets fired four rockets on a Hezbollah base midway between the neighboring villages of Jarjou and Ein Bouswar in the lighting air raid. A chain of loud explosions echoed across the area after the raid, which demolished a three-story house used by Hezbollah as an ammuntion dump and sniper nest on a hilltop overlooking the two villages. ``The house has been completely destroyed and many victims have been buried beneath the rubble,'' said a police spokesman, who could not be identified under standing rules. Flames and smoke shrouding the target could be seen from Nabatiyeh, Ein Bouswar and Jarjou, the spokesman and witnesses in Nabatiyeh said. A Hezbollah statement in Beirut said two party fighters were killed and many wounded. ``General mobilization has been ordered by the party in the area and all fighters were put on high alert to retaliate for the monstrous Israeli aggression,'' the statement said. It did not elaborate. Jarjou and Ein Bouswar are two to three miles north of Israel's self-declared security zone. Hezbollah has long been engaged in guerrilla attacks against Israeli troops and allied Lebanese Christian militiamen policing the zone. The zone's population is predominantly Moslem Shiite. Israel carved out the buffer area in 1985, saying it was needed to guard against cross-border raids. Israeli jets on Friday attacked bases of radical Palestinian guerrillas in Syrian-policed northern and eastern Lebanon. Eight fighters were wounded. The targets were positions of the Libyan-funded, Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. The attack last week was the first into Lebanon since Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir formed his right-wing government last month. Arab governments have called it a ``war government.'' Sunday's was Israel's 14th air attack this year. By police count, 16 people were killed and 39 wounded in the 13 previous strikes since Jan. 19. Also in south Lebanon, a street battle broke out late Saturday afternoon in the port city of Sidon between Palestinian fundamentalists and Lebanese Sunni Moslem militiamen of the Nasserite Popular Organization. Police said Sunday two people were killed and 21 wounded in the eight-hour clash that involved automatic rifles, rocket-launched grenades and mortars. They said the clashes between the Ansarullah, anewly founded Palestinian faction, and the Nasserites were halted by an informal cease-fire at 1 a.m. Sunday. Ansarullah, Arabic for ``God's partisans,'' comprises Moslem extremists from the Palestinian refugee camp of Ein el-Hilweh, on the outskirts of Sidon. The faction is allied with Hamas, the Palestinian resistance group based in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. The Nasserites are the dominant militia in Sidon, a predominantly Sunni Moslem area. They maintain close ties with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization, whose efforts to negotiate a peace with Israel have been openly criticized by Hamas. Hamas has been challenging the pro-PLO underground command of the Arab uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Novel Sentence: Write Me From Prison
DOC.TEXT: A judge who wanted vivid descriptions of criminal life so he could warn young people away from lawlessness has ordered convicted criminals to write him letters from jail. Judge Raymond R. Norko, the presiding judge at the court that handles serious crimes in Hartford County, recently has been ordering defendants to write him letters recounting how their lives led to prison. Norko, who promises convicts their names will not be released with their letters, said he hopes to put together a collection that he can publish and distribute to schoolchildren. ``Maybe to have it in writing would be more vivid and real for them,'' he said. Norko said he has received only three responses, so he has started handing out the assignment before sentencing. One letter he received was written with large, childlike lettering. ``Why I started doing drugs: I wish I could say it was because my friends were doing it. That was part of it,'' said the letter from a 23-year-old man who received a suspended sentence and probation for drug possession. ``The rest was because it made me feel good. ``I wish I could go back a couple of years and start over,'' the convict wrote. ``I have hurt a lot of people.'' Another convict wrote a chilling 12-page account of his life of crime. ``Let me start by saying I wish I were in your seat hearing these words instead of writing them,'' the man wrote. The author, now 36 and facing 11 years in prison, described a boyhood spent stealing cigarettes and sniffing glue, and then using drugs. ``Believe me when I tell you that once I made the choice to do drugs all my other choices were made for me,'' he wrote. After serving time in California, the convict wrote, he returned to Hartford, where he developed a $500-per-day crack habit. He wrote that he would often go four days without sleep, and overdosed so often he was embarrassed to show up at the hospital. ``I felt like an idiot every time I went,'' he wrote. ``Then when it was over and I could leave the hospital, I'd go right out and get high again.'' He had this advice for his readers: ``If you're doing drugs now I won't tell you to stop. You have to make the decision to get help for yourself. I will, however, tell you one thing your dealer doesn't tell you. All drugs come with a triple guarantee. 1) Jails 2) Institutions 3) Death.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Hundreds of Thousands Confronted By Criminals With Handguns
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 4th graf, ``The study xxx to delete redundant reference to number in lead and point out that no state and local breakdown available; subs 9th graf, ``Seventy-two xxx to include accounting of unknown and reporting category to make percentages add to 100; subs last two grafs prev with one graf to clarify comparison of statistics
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 639,000 Americans are confronted each year by criminals carrying handguns, including 9,200 people who are killed and 15,000 left wounded, according to a report released Sunday. A Justice Department study of crime statistics covering 1979 through 1987 showed that 44 percent of all people murdered during the nine-year period were killed by assailants wielding handguns. Guns were used in 7 percent of the rapes, 18 percent of robberies and 22 percent of the aggravated assaults during the period considered by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. The study was based on victims' reports taken by the department's annual National Crime Survey. It did not break down the figures by state or city. In an average year during the period, there were 9,200 murders, 12,100 rapes, 210,000 robberies and 407,600 assaults committed by criminals with handguns, the Justice Department said. An average of 15,000 people a year are wounded by assailants possessing handguns, the agency said. Fifty-one percent of the murders and non-negligent manslaughters committed by people with handguns occurred when shots were fired during an argument or a fight, according to the study. It said also that 25 percent of such killings took place during the commission of another crime. In an average year, the Justice Department said approximately 27 percent of the 2.3 million crimes involving weapons of any sort were committed by people with handguns. Other types of guns accounted for 8 percent, or 180,100 of such crimes. Seventy-two percent of the handgun crimes were committed by people who were strangers to the victim, the department said. Acquaintances carrying guns committed 17 percent of those crimes. Relatives of the victim committed 5 percent of handgun crimes. The other 6 percent were in the ``unknown'' or ``unreported'' categories. Americans living in cities, particularly black men between the ages of 16 and 24, were more likely to encounter criminals armed with handguns, the study said. The rate of handgun crimes was 5.9 per 1,000 city dwellers versus 2.7 per 1,000 among suburban residents and 1.7 among residents of non-metropolitan areas, the Justice Department reported. There were 32 handgun crimes per 1,000 urban black males between the ages of 16 and 24, compared to 14 per 1,000 for white city dwellers in the same age bracket.

DOC.HEAD: Source: Prominent Human Rights Figure Seeks Asylum at U.S. Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with unconfirmed reports that three dead in unrest. Pickup pvs 13th graf, `Regarding Muite...'
DOC.TEXT: A prominent human rights lawyer under threat of arrest for his criticism of Kenya's one-party government has sought refuge at the U.S. Embassy, a source said Sunday. Also Sunday, stone-throwing demonstrators confronted police in Nairobi's commercial center, where a day earlier police had fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse a pro-democracy rally. Witnesses said they saw at least two people injured Sunday. There were unconfirmed reports that three people were killed. By late Sunday afternoon, at least three trucks carrying scores of heavily armed troops had moved into the area. Riot police bearing clubs were seen in surrounding neighborhoods occasionally firing canisters of tear gas to break up groups. In once incident, police using a club beat a man who was subsequently hospitalized. Elsewhere, a youth was crushed between a bus and a van in an accident caused when bystanders started throwing stones at traffic, a witness said. Human rights Lawyer Gibson Kamau Kuria, a former detainee who in 1988 won the Robert F. Kennedy human rights award, had gone into hiding late Thursday after the government detained at least 12 advocates of multiparty democracy. It was unclear when Kuria, 43, reportedly moved into the U.S. mission in downtown Nairobi. But the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the lawyer was there. U.S. officials, including Ambassador Smith Hempstone, refused comment on the status of Kuria or Paul Muite, another lawyer who also went into hiding after last week's arrests. The United States has criticized the crackdown on the opposition, and the ruling party's newspaper threatened the U.S. ambassador with expulsion in an editorial on Sunday that was titled: ``Shut up, Mr. Ambassador.'' Saturday, riots erupted after a rally supporting multiparty democracy turned violent and police dispersed the crowd with gunfire and tear gas. Police pursued demonstrators into Nairobi's commerical center and the disturbances quickly spread throughout the city. But by nightfall, only small bands of demonstrators remained, playing cat-and-mouse with the troops. Newspapers said scores of people were injured in Saturday's violence. Hospitals provided no casualty figures and the government issued no comment. Regarding Muite, his wife and associates said the lawyer was safe, but would not reveal his whereabouts. Philip Kilonzo, Kenya's national police chief, said authorities still were trying to find the two lawyers. ``We have not given up our efforts to get them,'' he was quoted as saying in Sunday editions of the ruling party's English-language newspaper, the Kenya Times. The U.S. State Department protested the arrests in a statement last week. ``These actions only serve to tarnish Kenya's image in the international community,'' the State Department said in a comment issued Saturday. Previous U.S. suggestions that Kenya consider multipary democracy have angered the government, which at one point threatened to curtail Hempstone's movement. President Daniel arap Moi has rejected the idea, and Cabinet ministers have called those backing such moves subversives. Moi repeatedly has threatened to arrest opponents. He claims the existence of about 40 tribes in Kenya would invite tribal-based parties, leading to ethnic divisions and even warfare. On Sunday, the ruling party newspaper responded to the State Department's recent comments in an editorial. It described Hempstone as the ``epitome of developed-world conceit of the vilest kind'' and threatened him with expulsion. He ``will have only himself to blame should Kenya find it necessary to declare him a persona non grata,'' it said. ``He should remember that he is a diplomat, a person sent by his government to promote good will between states, and not an international political terrorist,'' said the editorial. ``Diplomacy is most effectively conducted quietly, and not through self-righteous pronouncements.'' Hempstone seemed unruffled by the editorial, which he described in a telephone interview as ``an outrageous piece of work.'' The United States is a major donor to Kenya, whose economy is heavily dependent on foreign aid. Last year the U.S. gave $61 million in economic aid and $15 million in military assistance, according to a study prepared by The Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Settle In For Wait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 22nd graf `Hungarian TV...' with seven grafs to add details on scene at Hungarian embassy, Hungarian television interview with pretender to Albanian throne. Pickup 23rd graf pvs `In Geneva ...' ^LaserPhotos PAR3, PAR4
DOC.TEXT: A promise of freedom secured, thousands of Albanians in Tirana settled in Sunday for an uncomfortable wait in crammed foreign embassies surrounded by vigilant police. Foreign governments, already pondering the logistics of evacuating the Albanians in their missions and resettling them abroad, were faced with the more immediate problem of housing and feeding them in the meantime. More than 5,000 people were sheltered in missions, some of them overcrowded. The situation appeared worst in the West German mission, which was overflowing with 3,000 Albanians. The Italian and French embassies also reported difficulties in taking care of the refugees. A baby girl was born during the night in the West German mission. Security forces were back on duty Sunday. They were withdrawn from the area late last week under foreign pressure following reports that they had shot at asylum-seekers scrambling up embassy walls. The French Foreign Ministry reported that the diplomatic quarter was sealed off Sunday by 600 police officers and soldiers who blocked anyone from getting through. Austrian TV said police roadblocks had been set up on main roads into Tirana. On Saturday, Albanian Foreign Ministry officials told diplomats that the Albanians in the embassies would be allowed to leave under foreign supervision. The officials said embassy personnel could accompany the asylum-seekers as they picked up travel documents and left the country. But only those accepted as refugees by foreign countries would be allowed to leave, the diplomats said. A Hungarian diplomat said the embassies were told they had to arrange transport for any Albanians they accepted. No departures were expected for days while arrangements were made for travel documents and transportation. There were no reports Sunday of unrest. On Saturday, thousands gathered near embassy row for silent rallies against Communist rule, Austria's APA news agency said. The turmoil at the embassies appeared to contribute to a shake-up Saturday of the ruling Politburo and Central Committee. One Politburo member was dismissed, three other functionaries were retired and the police minister and minister of war were fired. The reorganization was reported by the state ATA news agency and state-run television. The reports named Hekuran Isai as the new police minister and Kico Mustaqi as the new minister of war. Mustaqi is believed to be more moderate than his predecessor, but Isai had already held the ministry under the late Enver Hoxha and was considered close to the founder of Communist Albania. His reappointment indicated a determination to keep a tight rein on dissent. Some foreign missions lacked sufficient food and water for the refugees and hygenic conditions were poor, officials said Sunday. They said Albanian authorities were not allowing foreign governments to send supplies. ``The situation in our embassy, but in other embassies as well, has become intolerable,'' West Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told West German television. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry described the situation at its embassy as increasingly difficult, with inadequate sanitary facilities and a lack of medicine. There was no word of major illness. The embassy was sheltering more than 500 Albanians, and a French doctor was seeing 60 patients a day, many of whom were injured while scaling the compound's fence, said the ministry. Italian Sen. Franco Salvi said in Rome after returning from a private visit to Tirana that 900 Albanian asylum-seekers wanted to come to his country. ``We hope we can welcome them in a dignified way,'' he said. ``We just can't throw them in some camp.'' The ambassador's wife was forced to buy food at the local market to feed those in the mission, Salvi said. Two prefabricated huts were hastily erected on embassy grounds to house some of the Albanians. Hungarian television news showed a small but jubilant crowd in the Hungarian embassy, waving their passport application forms and flashing V-for-victory signs. A Hungarian diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, described the mood among the approximately 40 Albanians in the embassy as optimistic. He said the Albanians had received a Red Cross shipment of clothes, were exercising regularly in the embassy garden, and were filling out forms to receive their travel documents. ``We are all set to take the forms to the Foreign Ministry tomorrow morning and to discuss what the next step will be,'' the diplomat said. Hungarian television also broadcast an interview with Leka I, the pretender to the Albanian throne who is now an arms dealer in South Africa. Speaking from his farm near Johannesburg, Leka called for the overthrow of the Communist regime and claimed he had support ``in the security service, in the army, and ... even ... some party member supporters.'' Leka is the son of King Zog, the last Albanian monarch who abdicated after World War II. In Geneva on Sunday, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he had sent a Swedish U.N. diplomat to Tirana to obtain firsthand information on the situation. During 45 years of hard-line Communist rule, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible. But Albanian leaders have sought better ties abroad since 1985, and they recently began to implement some reforms. A package of new regulations that took effect Tuesday entitled all Albanians over age 16 to own a passport. Communist leader Ramiz Alia decreed several measures Saturday to reform Albania's command economy, including the introduction of small-scale private enterprise. But he did not mention the embassy standoff or promise political reforms. The reported breakthrough on the embassy crisis came hours after Albanian legislators guaranteed citizens could leave the embassies without fear of punishment. The parliamentary decree, published by ATA, was the first pledge with the force of law that Albanians in the foreign missions could receive passports without fear of prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Wins Soccer's Most Coveted Trophy
DOC.TEXT: Andreas Brehme scored a penalty goal with just six minutes left Sunday to beat defending champion Argentina and bring soccer's World Cup trophy back to West Germany for a third time. After the match, Argentine coach Carlos Bilardo rushed onto the field to pull his players away from Mexican referee Edgardo Codesal. He was being pushed and bumped as players angrily protested the penalty point that won the match. The mostly German crowd of more than 73,000 roared approval when Codesal signaled that defender Roberto Sensini had fouled striker Rudi Voeller. Brehme scored, kicking the ball into the lower left corner of the net past the outstretched goalie, Sergio Goycoechea. The win ended years of frustrations for the West Germans, World Cup runner-up against Italy in 1982 and against Argentina in 1986. West Germany has now joined Italy and Brazil as the only three-time winners of the tournament. Argentine defender Nestor Lorenzo left the field in tears with blood dripping from his mouth. His teammates seemed stunned by the penalty and the loss that ended Argentina's hopes of becoming the first team to win two consecutive cups since Italy did so in 1938. After the award ceremony, joyous German players took a victory lap around the stadium, rushing toward the delirious, singing, cheering, flag-waving German fans and holding the trophy triumphantly over their heads. West Germany's victory comes after a month of heart-touching triumph and dream-shattering defeats for the other 23 teams in the finals. No other competition stirs passions and national pride as much as this tournament for soccer's most coveted trophy. Italy's state-owned RAI television network, which made live coverage of the 52 matches available to about 150 countries, said an average of 400 million viewers saw each game. When England lost to West Germany in the semifinals, fans went on a rampage in nearly 30 English cities. More than 500 people were arrested and 35 police officers injured in a night of brawling and vandalism. By contrast, in Yaounde, Cameroon, most of the capital's 1 million residents thronged the streets to welcome back the national team that staged the biggest upset in World Cup history, beating Argentina 1-0 in the opening match. Cameroon also beat Romania and made it to the second round of the tournament, one the great surprises of the competition. World Cup veterans said the 1990 tournament lacked some of the drama of earlier cups. Still, it had its moments. Italy's Salvatore Schillaci mesmerized a nation with his uncanny ability to find the opening, the ball and the net. The pride of Sicily was the Cup's top scorer with six goals. Cameroon's Roger Milla provided some of the most enduring images of this World Cup, dancing in the corners after he scored. The comparatively old, 38-year-old substitute came out of retirement and off the bench to score four World Cup goals. But there were other enduring images, such as blue-helmeted police using tear gas and truncheons disperse rowdy fans who hurled stones, bottles or chairs at police, rivals or each other. Italian authorities stationed thousands of police at stadiums and banned the sale of alcoholic beverages on match days in cities where games were played.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Police, Strikers Face Off After Week of Walkouts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with President Chamorro urging workers to return to job; no pickup. ^By RODOLFO GARCIA
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on Sunday urged thousands of striking Sandinista workers to return to the job after police threatened to intervene to reopen shuttered workplaces. But the strikers vowed to keep them shut in the week-old wave of walkouts to protest government policy. ``It is the obligation of all workers to go back to work tomorrow,'' the president told The Associated Press in an interview Sunday. A police communique, released Saturday evening, said, ``Police will guarantee workers free access to their respective job sites'' beginning Monday. The communique also warned citizens not to disturb the peace, conduct street demonstrations without permission or block traffic. The police warning will not convince an estimated 90,000 strikers to back off from their demands, Sandinista National Labor Front head Lucio Jimenez told reporters. ``Faced with a position of force, we have to respond the same way,'' Jimenez said Saturday. The government has tried to head off the strike with economic concessions, but workers have held out with political demands. On Friday, Finance Minister Emilio Pereira announced a 43 percent wage increase for civil servants in lower pay brackets, plus cost-of-living increases for 65,000 of the government's 100,000 workers. But National Labor Front leader Jose Angel Bermudez said the offer was an effort to fool state employees. ``It's an attempt to get the workers back on the job and buy off their just demands by means of a solemn joke about salaries,'' Bermudez said. He said inflation will eat up the earnings and massive firings are in the offing. Government agricultural, industrial, service and office workers are demanding a new minimum wage, job security, protection of peasant land distributed under land reforms of the former leftist Sandinista administration, financing for industrial ventures and the opening of new construction projects. Private sector employees have joined the government workers in demands for more participation in economic policy-making. The workers are allied with the Sandinista Front, which remains the largest single political bloc in Nicaragua. The series of strikes is the second in the 2-month-old administration of Mrs. Chamorro. Mrs. Chamorro was the candidate of the U.S.-backed United National Opposition coalition in the Feb. 25 elections, in which she beat Sandinista party incumbent Daniel Ortega. She is trying to reverse his party's centralized government policy and replace it with free-market strategy.
