DOC.HEAD: Mayor Overrules Motion That Would Have Allowed Beach Boys Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name to Carmen sted Carmon in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of this resort town overruled a city council decision to allow a Beach Boys concert here, saying the town's ``silent majority'' opposed the performance. After a heated debate, council members Friday night approved by a 5-3 vote a request by the California group's promoter Rick Tisdale for permission to sell and distribute up to 15,000 tickets for the Aug. 26 concert on the beach. But Mayor Carmen Bunch said the council ignored pressing traffic conditions and safety concerns created by the concert. She said the city's ``silent majority, the type of people who don't attend meetings,'' were opposed to the concert. The Beach Boys decided to move their benefit performance for the city's fire department to a park in Ladson, about 20 miles inland from Isle of Palms.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Celebrate World Cup Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with one fan killed, one injured, Nazi salutes in East Germany. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: West Germans poured into the streets drinking champagne and setting off endless rounds of fireworks Sunday night to fete their team's 1-0 triumph over Argentina in the World Cup soccer championship. In Berlin, victory celebrations almost matched the madhouse scenes that accompanied the opening of the Berlin Wall in November. Hundreds of people popped champagne corks and trampled on the bottles, leaving many downtown areas littered with glass. Others drank beer and danced on car tops. Some celebrating East Germans gave the Nazi outstretched-hand salute. In Cologne, West Germany, one frenzied fan jumped out of a streetcar window and died when he was run over by a car, police said. Several scuffles with police were also reported. In Hamburg, about 20,000 fans massed in the St. Pauli district, many of them throwing bottles and fireworks at police. At least one person was injured. Thousands of people crowded the elegant Kurfuerstendamm shopping street in West Berlin, many carrying huge West German flags to celebrate the victory in Rome. ``What a celebration!'' said the announcer on West Germany's ARD television network. ``I think that for many people, this Sunday will have more than 24 hours.'' The soccer victory capped an amazing year for the Germans, who are expecting full unification of their two nations within months. ``East, West: it doesn't make any difference. It's just Germany,'' said a jubilant Reyk Burghardt, a 20-year-old railroad worker from East Berlin, as he waved a West German flag. In Berlin, the constant sound of fireworks rumbled through the cool night air, and bright lights flashed across the city. ``O-le, O-le, O-le, O-le!'' people shouted at the top of their lungs, using the Spanish greeting ``Ole,'' a traditional cry in soccer stadiums. ARD television provided live shots of fans waving flags and cheering wildly. ``I can't even hear myself,'' the television's reporter complained as he waded into the crowd. In East Berlin, thousands of raucous youths smashed bottles, overturned tables, destroyed concession tents and tipped over a giant keg of beer in the sprawling plaza in front of the Old Museum, where a 40-foot television screen had been set up. Marina Hinz said she felt ``joy, nothing but joy.'' She also carried a huge West German flag. The celebrations stretched throughout West Germany, from Flensburg in the north to Bavaria in the south. Huge victory parades blocked city centers in Munich, Stuttgart, Frankfurt, Cologne and other major cities.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Get Early Start at Summit
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 advocates of more spending on AIDs research marched through downtown Houston Sunday on the eve of the 16th economic summit of the world's richest nations. The demonstrators carried signs and flags from each of the seven countries attending the summit. ``Our message to the world leaders is `Get off the stick and help health worldwide,''' said Bob Kunst, executive director of Miami-based Cure AIDS Now, which sponsored the march. ``There is no international plan to cure AIDS and that's why we are here _ to demand it,'' Kunst said. Later in the day, protesters demonstrated against protesters in a park across from the gates of Rice University, where the summit will commence Monday. Anti-abortion demonstrators were mocked by a dozen members of a separate AIDs group, Act Up, who in turn were derided by a similarly small contingent from the American Family Association, an anti-gay group. Police drew their riot sticks at one point, but no violence erupted and no arrests were made. The anti-abortion demonstrators, representing 50 Houston area churches, planted 4,400 crosses in what they called the ``Cemetery of Innocents'' to symbolize the number of reported daily abortions in America.

DOC.HEAD: Six Workers Injured in Finale of Bay City Fireworks Festival
DOC.TEXT: An aerial rocket misfired, sparking an explosion that injured six workers at the Bay City Fireworks Festival, authorities said Sunday. About 100,000 people had gathered along the banks of the Saginaw River Saturday night for the festival's finale and Gov. James Blanchard had just left the firing area when the accident occurred, state police said. A 10- to 12-inch fireworks shell ``exploded just as it was clearing the mortar tube,'' said policewoman Linda Collier. ``It blew low and ignited three or four other firecracker shells near it.'' One of the Wolverine Fireworks workers, Terry McPeak, was in serious condition at Bay Medical Center, hospital spokeswoman Sharon Dewaele said. Technician Patrick Myer and Michigan State Police Sgt. Robert Harkin were in fair condition, Dewaele said. Pyrotechnicians Bob Carrigan and Scott Robertson were treated and discharged from the medical center, she said. The sixth worker, Dave Byer, was taken to Saint Mary's Hospital in Saginaw where he was in fair condition, said a nursing supervisor who declined to be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Ride 'Em Cowboy: Bush Hosts Rodeo and Barbecue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with barbeque color, edits to shorten
DOC.TEXT: It was bodacious Texas fun. With cattle lowing in the background and dust swirling through the air, the leaders of the free world threw horseshoes, sampled barbeque and watched cowboys at work Sunday evening. President Bush appeared to delight in showing his VIP guests a country-style evening of entertainment before they turned their attention to Monday's economic summit opening. They tramped through sawdust-covered artificial turf to a horseshoe pit and took a turn at Bush's favorite pasttime. The president out-pitched his guests, landing two ringers. Then they trooped through a buffet line, plates awkwardly in hand, to sample some of the 3{ tons of meat barbecued for the occasion. The president also lined up a rodeo and a rare out-of-town performance by the Grand Ole Opry for his guests' amusement. The men were dressed casually: Bush and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney both sported the fancy ostrich cowboy boots made especially for the economic summit. Japan's leader, Toshiki Kaifu, showed off an oversize western belt buckle. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher picked her way through the sawdust in white-and-black heels. Cowboys were competing in such events as bareback riding, bull riding, barrel racing and calf scramble, said Dan Gaddis of the Houston Livestock Show & Rodeo, an annual affair that draws more than a million people each winter. ``What could be better than a rodeo, great country music and `the taste as big as Texas,''' said Mike Jolley, president of Houston-based Luther's Bar-B-Q Inc., which was providing the food for the rodeo party, which was expected to draw several thousand people. It took 140 workers more than four days to slow cook all that barbecue, including brisket, sausage, chicken and ribs. Crews also made more than 1{ tons of coleslaw, potato salad and beans. Naturally, there were also 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce, pickles and jalapenos, 500 pounds of onions, more than 5,000 servings of cobbler and carrot cake and 650 gallons of lemonade and iced tea. Bush and the foreign leaders were dining on china made by Austin, Texas, potter Teri Vance Hubbeling, who said she had worked nearly non-stop since being asked to create the 63 festive plates with a Texas theme. She designed three different patterns _ a centered longhorn with green cactus in the background and blue trim, a race horse with boots in the background and a longhorn with barbed wire in the background. Rocky Carroll, who has made numerous boots for Bush, said he worked about 40 hours to create each pair of the full-quill ostrich boots for the visiting leaders. The boots sport the seven flags of the participating nations across the top. Each boot's center front has a Texas flag and ``Houston'' stitched along the bottom. The leaders' initials are stitched in gold along the side. ``These are the finest pair of boots I've ever made,'' said Carroll, owner of R.J.'s Boot Co. in Houston. Carroll also provided the sterling silver belt buckles with gold inlay, beaver cowboy hats and boot bags. The Grand Ole Opry presented mandolins for the leaders. The Opry performance marked only the second time in 40 years the country show had left its Nashville home. The first was in 1988, for a special show in Tampa, Fla., in connection with the Hall of Fame football game. Besides Minnie Pearl and Charley Pride, stars on hand were to include Loretta Lynn and Larry Gatlin and the Gatlin Brothers.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Loss, Argentina Celebrates World Cup Final
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of soccer fans, many wrapped in the national flag, filled the capital's streets Sunday to mark their team's second place finish in World Cup soccer. The fans shouted, sang, danced and blew horns and whistles to celebrate, despite Argentina's 1-0 loss to West Germany in Rome. Argentina was the defending champion. ``Win or lose, we love the national team,'' chanted more than 3,000 celebrating fans gathered in the Plaza of the Republic in Buenos Aires. President Carlos Menem, who watched the game on a giant television screen in Government House, echoed the sentiments of many fans when he said that West Germany played masterfully. However, he also criticized the referee who awarded the penalty shot that allowed Germany to score its lone goal with just six minutes left. ``Germany took the ball and dominated play,'' said Menem in a statement. ``Argentina was an incomplete team, and we lost with an unfair goal because the penalty was not merited.'' ``As far as the referee is concerned,'' Menem added, ``he should take up medicine.'' Referee Edgardo Codesal ordered the penalty shot and expelled Argentina's Pedro Monzon late in the game. Jose Maria Pedrazo, a fan, said Argentina ``was lucky to reach the finals and West Germany deserved the victory _ but not that kind of victory, not on a penalty.'' Pedrazo and his wife, Elvira, were in the Plaza of the Republic joining the celebrations. Sunday was treated like a national holiday in Argentina. The sky-blue and white national flag was hung from windows and balconies of thousands of high-rise apartments. Many Argentines called friends to organize parties to watch the game. Sidewalk entrepreneurs sold flags, hats, and banners with a likeness of Diego Maradona, Argentina's team captain. Police, seeking to head off a repeat of the vandalism and looting that followed Argentina's semi-finals victory over Italy, stationed 5,000 officers in the downtown area. Two people were killed and 200 arrested in incidents after the win over Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Companies Withheld Information on Dangers at Jacksonville Plant
DOC.TEXT: Two of the country's largest chemical companies withheld information from employees on the toxic nature of dioxin wastes at a local chemical plant, a newspaper reported Sunday. Officials of Hercules Inc. and Dow Chemical also knew about dangers of dioxins, a class of chemicals generally considered unwanted byproducts that may cause a range of ailments, as early as 1965 and were concerned the government would learn about the dangers, the Arkansas Democrat reported. Hercules operated the Jacksonville chemical plant and Dow contracted with Hercules to produce herbicides, including 2,4,5-T, a dioxin-contaminated herbicide. Hercules also made the dioxin-tainted defoliant Agent Orange at the plant from 1967-70. The newspaper said it obtained memos beginning in 1965 from chemical company officials in Delaware, Michigan, Germany and Arkansas that show wastes at the Jacksonville plant were tested for dioxin, which had caused outbreaks of a skin ailment called chloracne in chemical plant workers in the United States and abroad. Hercules, Dow and Jacksonville plant officials knew as early as April 1, 1965, that dioxin was ``highly toxic'' and ``capable of inducing a disfiguring disease from dermal (skin) exposure to very small amounts,'' an internal Hercules memorandum said, the newspaper said. Officials of both Dow and Hercules declined comment on the memos. Management didn't tell employees they were working with dioxin for many years _ not until publicity about the chemical began appearing _ and then downplayed its dangers, workers told the newspaper. ``They never explained the danger to us. They never stressed the danger to us,'' said Joe Bolden, who worked at the plant for nine years. He said workers would frequently get burned by the chemicals. ``If something got on you, you would go to the laboratory and they said it's not going to hurt you. Just take a shower,'' Bolden said. ``I remember people talking about dioxin. They said we had it but not to the extent that it would hurt anybody. I didn't get anything officially from anybody,'' said Luster Kennedy Jr., a former plant safety director. The newspaper said one memo sent on July 12, 1965, by J.R. Frawley, a toxicologist at Hercules' corporate office in Wilmington, Del., to two officials at the Jacksonville plant summarized a telephone call he received from Earl Farnham of Dow. Dow was concerned about an ``acnegen,'' or dioxin, causing chloracne in workers at its 2,4,5-T plant in Midland, Mich. ``They are aware that their competitors are marketing 2,4,5-T, which contains `alarming amounts' of acnegen and if the government learns of this, the whole industry will suffer. They are particularly fearful of a congressional investigation and excessive restrictive legislation on manufacture of pesticides might result,'' Frawley wrote. Vertac Chemical Corp. of Memphis bought the plant in 1976. It ceased production in 1986 but did not abandon the site. The site is 18th on the federal government's Superfund list, a roster of more than 1,000 of the nation's hazardous chemical sites. Later this year, incineration is scheduled for nearly 30,000 drums of hazardous wastes stored at the site.

DOC.HEAD: Monument to Holocaust Victims Unveiled in Budapest
DOC.TEXT: A monument dedicated to the 600,000 Hungarian Jews who died in the Nazi Holocaust was unveiled Sunday at the gates of this city's former Jewish ghetto. About 1,000 people, including some Holocaust survivors, attended the unveiling ceremony for the monument, which stands at the site of the mass grave of 6,000 Jews killed in Budapest. The huge black granite and steel memorial, designed by Imre Varga, one of Hungary's best known artists, depicts a weeping willow in the shape of an inverted menorah, the seven-branched Jewish candelabrum. Among the dignitaries on hand were Interim President Arpad Goencz, Prime Minister Jozsef Antall, World Jewish Congress President Edgar Bronfman, and film star Tony Curtis. He is the honorary chairman of the Emanuel Foundation, which raised funds for the monument. ``Over 40 years had to pass before Jews and non-Jews could gather here to remember the victims,'' said Goencz, a writer and former political prisoner. He was chosen as interim president in May by Hungary's new democratically elected parliament. ``The crimes of the Nazis cast a shadow over generations. This was not only a Jewish, but also a Hungarian tragedy.'' Antall pleaded for reconciliation between Christians and Jews, adding that ``this common tragedy has poisoned the atmosphere _ a poison present to this day.'' He pledged that Hungary's new non-Communist government ``will do its utmost to let Jews live in Hungary without fear.'' Bronfman noted that there have been increased signs of anti-Semitism in Hungary and other countries in Eastern Europe, which are making the ``painful' transition from a Communist command economy to a free market system. ``Human nature is such that some people require a scapegoat,'' Bronfman told reporters. He welcomed the new government's resolute stand against anti-Semitism and praised the former government for not bowing to Arab pressure to halt flights by the national airline Malev carrying Soviet Jews to Israel. About 80,000 Jews now live in Hungary, giving it Eastern Europe's second largest Jewish community after the Soviet Union. Before the Nazi Holocaust, 1 million Jews lived in Hungary. A total of about 6 million Jews died in Hungary and elsewhere during the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: PTA President Charged in Death of Infant in her Care
DOC.TEXT: A PTA president who cared for children in her home has been charged with murder in the death of a 9-month-old boy who suffered a fractured skull while in her care. Debra Cummings, 32, of Reseda, pleaded innocent Friday in Van Nuys Municipal Court. Cummings, the mother of a 6-year-old girl and the president of the Shirley Avenue Elementary School Parent Teachers Association, was ordered held without bail. The infant, Kevin Young, was in Cummings' care almost daily for six months. Cummings told police that Kevin, who died June 16 at a hospital, apparently fell and hit his head on a coffee table while she was in another room. But a coroner's report concluded the baby was hit with hands or fists. Authorities said they were investigating the death of another child who died in Cummings' care. Fourteen-month-old Matthew Cooley lost consciousness while he was at a park with Cummings last March. His doctor said his death was the result of a seizure.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Say No U.S. Troops Would Be Used In Reported Drug Raid
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials stopped short Sunday of denying a report that plans are being developed for a U.S.-coordinated military attack on drug lords in South America, but said there has been no change in the policy of not involving U.S. forces in direct operations. Newsweek reported Saturday it has obtained briefing papers from U.S. Southern Command headquarters in Panama that envision an attack coordinated by the Southern Command and using the armies of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru to attack drug-trafficking targets in those countries. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said on CNN's ``Newsmaker sunday'' that it would be a ``real misnomer'' to refer to the operations as a ``big drug raid'' as suggested by an interviewer. ``U.S. troops will be used the same way they've always been used,'' he said. ``That is, when asked for they will help train local military. They will not be used operationally. In interdiction and intelligence, for example, in tracking and so on, yes, we will use the military, as we have been doing it all along.'' Asked whether the reported operation signals an escalation of the drug war, Scowcroft said: ``No. Well, hopefully, it's an intensification, it's not an escalation. Newsweek said the attack would involve a massive use of force applied swiftly and simultaneously to ``the cartel's entire support structure,'' possibly targeting drug lords' homes, drug-processing centers and secret airfields used for smuggling. U.S. troops would direct the operation but would not take part in it unless ``the need arises,'' the magazine reported. ``Our policies are clear,'' said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``We're doing in Central America, Latin America, what we can to help those nations that are involved, where there is production. We only do what they ask us to do. Our involvement is limited in the sense that no U.S. forces are permitted to go out on operational assignments and no U.S. forces participate in any activities down there unless I've personally signed off on their presence in those countries.'' Cheney did not respond directly when pressed on CBS' ``Face the Nation'' to comment on specifics of the Newsweek account. ``I suppose you could argue that at present you've got a situation where the military units in those countries are actively involved in fighting the drug cartel and we are actively involved in supporting them ... by coordination and support and assistance,'' he said. Although the plan reportedly is almost ready to be carried out, Newsweek said members of Congress _ fearful the operation could escalate into another Vietnam, with high U.S. casualties _ were unlikely to view it favorably.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Shows Off Houston to Summit Partners

EDs. Leads with 4 grafs with rodeo color; pickup 2nd graf pvs: ``The economic,'' and deletes now redundant 11th graf pvs, `Later, out'' and subs last 2 grafs to make Kaifu reference conform and update with World Cup score
DOC.TEXT: President Bush showed off his adopted hometown to his summit partners Sunday, worshipping at church with Britain's Margaret Thatcher, shooting baskets at his favorite health club with Canada's Brian Mulroney and landing two ringers in a horseshoe-pitching display. He jogged with local runners in an urban park, sported a new pair of cowboy boots emblazoned with summit flags and the map of Texas, and played host at a down-home barbecue and rodeo for his summit guests and a thousands of others at an arena next to the Astrodome. Mulroney also wore new cowboy boots to the rodeo _ a present for all the summit leaders from presidential bootmaker Rocky Carroll of Houston _ and a 10-gallon hat. Mrs. Thatcher opted for white heels, but Bush assured reporters she, too, had gotten a pair of summit boots. Bush demonstrated his horseshoe prowess by tossing two ringers. Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu pitched a few, too, but with less success. The economic summit was still 24 hours away, and three summiteers _ France's Francois Mitterrand, Italy's Giulio Andreotti and West Germany's Helmut Kohl _ weren't even in town yet. But George Bush was enjoying himself. He began the sabbath at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, his parish from his days here as an oilman and then congressman. It's near both his old neighborhood and the Houstonian, the hotel where he now hangs his hat. With six priests on the altar, three altar boys and an altar girl, it was a high church communion service that drew not only Bush and wife Barbara but British Prime Minister Thatcher, her husband Denis and Secretary of State James Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and their wives. The Bushes, the Thatchers and the Bakers all took communion. Brady, a Roman Catholic, did not. Back at the Houstonian, Bush dropped his wife off and traded his suit and tie for sneakers, a summit T-shirt and gray shorts. After a short ride, he alighted from the presidential limousine in Memorial Park, where he set off down the exercise trail with his protocol chief, Joseph Reed, Secret Service agents and a pack of delighted local joggers. The entourage quickly swelled to more than three dozen, including a man pushing a baby in a stroller and a woman with two small dogs. When a reporter called out ``Houston's Hot'' _ the slogan the city has adopted for its $10 million summit festivities _ Bush took it literally and replied, ``No, it's not bad yet. Not bad. It's going good.'' As he waited beneath a maroon canopy at the Houstonian for Canadian Prime Minister Mulroney to arrive, Bush displayed a touch of reticence on summit substance, turning aside reporters' efforts to question him about a letter from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush did join the Canadian leader before the microphones to announce plans to launch negotiations on an acid rain agreement. Mulroney, who normally revels in give-and-take with reporters, followed his host's lead and beat a fast retreat afterward. ``We're going to head on in,'' Bush said, asking if Mulroney was going to take questions from the Canadian press. ``I think the Canadians have been in the heat too long,'' said Mulroney, turning his heels on a press corps that had stood in the sweltering heat for 45 minutes. The two men had a private lunch with their wives, then the president took the prime minister over to the Houstonian's million-dollar health club, where they shot a few baskets and checked out the other swank facilities. Only Mulroney, Thatcher, Kaifu and Jacques Delors, head of the European Community and the eighth summit principal, were in town for the rodeo and Grand Ole Opry concert. Mitterrand, Kohl and Andreotti were all due in Monday morning, shortly before the opening ceremonies at Rice University. The West German and the Italian spent their Sunday in Rome with their eyes riveted on the World Cup soccer final between West Germany and Argentina. Kohl was rewarded with a 1-0 triumph for his homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Eight Soldiers, Wound 16
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels detonated mines under a military truck and an armored car Sunday, killing eight government soldiers and injuring 16, officials said. It was the latest bloodshed in a 27-day-old round of fighting that has killed at least 2,109 combatants in the separatist war. The mines, buried in a road near Vavuniya, 140 miles north of Colombo, went off as the vehicles passed over them, military officials said. Also Sunday, President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed to the international community to help start peace talks with the separatist rebels. They began a new round of fighting on June 11 for control of the northeastern section of this island nation off the southern tip of India. ``It is only with the involvement of the international community in a manner acceptable to us that the dialogue can recommence,'' Premadasa told a meeting of government officials in Puttalam, 80 miles north of Colombo. The president did not elaborate on his statement, but government sources said Premadasa was making an indirect request to international organizations to mediate between the government and the rebel militia, known as the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. The government has so far maintained that talks can only begin if the Tamil Tigers lay down their arms. In the eastern town of Batticaloa, where the latest round of fighting began, six charred bodies were discovered Sunday. Residents of the port town, 135 miles east of Colombo, said the victims were young Tamil men, most likely civilians. Five charred bodies were also found Friday and Saturday in different places in Batticaloa, residents said on condition of anonymity. It was not immediately clear who killed them, but the killings have created panick in the government-controlled town. The government claims to control most of the eastern districts after rebels fled into the jungles, but acknowledges the north is still in rebel hands. On Saturday, government troops blew up a rebel ammunition dump and shot and killed 21 militants in the northeastern district of Trincomalee, a Defense Ministry statement said. The recent round of fighting ended a 13-month cease-fire. The Tamil Tigers are fighting for the independence of the Tamil-majority north and east from the rest of Sri Lanka, which is predominantly Sinhalese. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population and dominate the government, military and police. Tamil militants claim their community is discriminated against by the Sinhalese majority in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. More than 13,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explosion in Punjab Kills Two, Injures 35
DOC.TEXT: A powerful bomb exploded Sunday at a vegetable market in a town in the northern state of Punjab, killing two people and injuring 35, news reports said. There were no immediate claims of responsibility, but Sikh separatists seeking an independent nation were believed responsible. In other violence, Sikh militants killed at least 11 people on Saturday and Sunday in Punjab, United News of India said. The news agency said the bomb exploded in a shop in the town of Fatehgarh Churian, 22 miles north of Amritsar, the Sikh holy city. Amritsar, which is about 240 miles northwest of New Delhi, is the focal point of the Sikh separatist movement. At least 1,300 people have been killed in Punjab this year in violence linked to the separatist movement. Sikh militants have been demanding an independent state since 1982, accusing India's Hindu majority of political and cultural discrimination against their community. Sikhs represent only 2 percent of India's 880 million people but are in a majority in Punjab, a prosperous farming state bordering Pakistan. Hindus make up 82 percent of the country's population.

DOC.HEAD: Bulls Gore Three, Injure 32 During Famed Festival
DOC.TEXT: Three people were gored and 32 other people slightly injured Sunday in a running of the bulls at the storied San Fermin festival. They were hurt while testing their bravery by running in front of six bulls through cobblestoned streets for a half-mile to the city bullring. Navarre Hospital said Andres Barani, a 32-year-old Swede living in Madrid, was gored in the face. It said Jose Luis Place, a Frenchman, was gored in the buttocks. The third man, an unidentified Spaniard, was gored in the left thigh. Navarre Hospital said 32 other runners received treatment for bruises and scrapes. Dozens of young men took part in the event. The bulls run every morning at 8 a.m. and are killed in the afternoon in bulllfights. Sunday's running was the second in the weeklong festival. The bull running, made famous by American author Ernest Hemingway, are part of a non-stop drinking and dancing festival in honor of San Fermin, the city's patron saint. The festival began Saturday and is to continue through July 14. One Spaniard was seriously injured and 58 others received on-site treatment Saturday. The festival, which attracts thousands of tourists from around the world every year, was the setting for Hemingway's 1926 novel ``The Sun Also Rises.'' The novel described in detail the rowdy, round-the-clock festival that awakens with the morning run of the bulls. Except during war years, the festival has been held continously since 1591. Since then, bulls have gored to death 52 people, 13 of them since 1924 when Hemingway first visited Pamplona.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 30 Boats Join Greenpeace Protest Outside U.S. Base
DOC.TEXT: More than 30 Japanese rubber boats, kayaks and other small craft joined a Greenpeace yacht Sunday in an anti-nuclear demonstration off a U.S. Navy base near Tokyo, a Japanese officials said. Protesters on the boats shouted, ``Don't bring nuclear weapons into Japan!'' said an official of the Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard. Led by the 38-foot Greenpeace yacht Vega, the Japanese boats formed a circular peace sign in the water, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said nine patrol boats were mobilized to prevent the protest boats from sailing into the base at Yokosuka, 28 miles southwest of Tokyo. He said there were no clashes between demonstrators and coast guard patrols. The environmental group's yacht carried three crew members from the United States, New Zealand and Australia and a Japanese interpreter, the official said. The group has offices in London and Washington. At a park near the U.S. base, about 100 Japanese held a rally to demand that U.S. Navy ships not bring any nuclear weapons into Japan, the official added. On Friday, the Vega, displaying anti-nuclear signs, trailed the 67,000-ton U.S. aircraft carrier Midway out of Yokosuka, its home port. Faith Doherty, Pacific coordinator for Greenpeace's Nuclear Free Seas campaign, said the protest marked the start of a 1{-month voyage around Japan by the Vega to educate people about the dangers of nuclear weapons and nuclear propulsion. The Midway is not nuclear-powered, but many Japanese claim that it and other U.S. Navy ships using Japanese ports carry nuclear weapons in violation of a Japanese ban. The subject is sensitive in Japan, the only nation ever attacked with atomic bombs. The United States refuses to comment on the location of any of its nuclear weapons. But the Japanese government has said the United States would need Japan's permission to bring in such weapons but never has sought such authorization.

DOC.HEAD: Emerald Miners Sign Peace Accord in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Emerald miners have signed a peace accord, a mining official announced Sunday, after seven years of warfare that killed an estimated 3,000 people. The so-called ``Emerald Wars'' have also exacerbated violence perpetrated by drug traffickers, leftist guerrillas and private right-wing armies. Four warring groups signed the peace accord, Jose Forero, manager of Emeralds of Colombia mining company, said in a communique. The four emerald-mining groups agreed to stop shooting at each other and allow the courts to decide disputes. The groups have been seeking to gain control of the rich emerald mines in eastern Colombia. Emeralds are one of Colombia's largest legal exports. The war has forced thousands of residents to flee their homes. Violence has restricted transportation and cut off food supplies. There have been reports of alliances and clashes between miners and drug dealers. Some drug lords reportedly have large investments in the mining operations. In another development in Colombia's second-largest city, Medellin, six policemen were assassinated since Friday night, police said Sunday. The deaths raised to 136 the number of law enforcement officials murdered this year in the city, home to the country's leading cocaine cartel. The report said five of the policemen were off-duty, unarmed and in civilian dress when they were killed. The sixth was in uniform and patrolling the streets on a motorcycle when he was killed, it said. After one killing, soldiers chased, shot and killed two of the assassins, the police report said. Authorities have blamed the assassinations on drug traffickers who are fighting a U.S.-backed government crackdown on the cocaine trade. Drug cartels are reportedly paying $4,300 for each assassination of a law enforcement official.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He'll Brief Summit Leaders on Gorbachev Aid Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fourth graf new with Bush remark. May stand for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush threw a Texas-style welcome for Western leaders Sunday on the eve of an economic summit already divided by an appeal from Mikhail S. Gorbachev for aid to bolster the crumbling Soviet economy. U.S. and British officials dug in their heels against direct aid. But Prime Minister Brian Mulroney was more sympathetic, extending commercial credits to Moscow and saying, ``Houston has to provide the beginnings of an economic response.'' Bush said he would present a letter from Gorbachev when leaders of the world's seven richest democracies convene Monday for their 16th annual economic summit. The letter, dispatched July 4, came to Bush in his role as summit host. ``Tomorrow we go to work,'' Bush told a cheering audience after a festive night of pre-summit partying. ``I think we're all working for the same thing, for world peace, for harmony in this exciting world we're living in.'' To strengthen the Soviet case for aid, foreign ministry spokesman Gennadi Gerasimov said Moscow was taking steps demanded by Bush. He said the military was being cut down to size, and that Moscow's huge subsidies to Cuba would ``fade away, but not tomorrow.'' Two of the western leaders delayed their arrivals to attend the World Cup soccer championship in Rome. Helmut Kohl cheered West Germany to a 1-0 victory over Argentina, and Italy's Giulio Andreotti was there to present the trophy. Trade and environmental issues were being aired at the summit, but the question of direct aid to Moscow topped the agenda. The United States, Japan and Britain said Moscow wasn't ready for aid from the West, while West Germany, France and Italy were ready to plunge ahead. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Sunday: ``We don't believe that they (the Soviets) have the economic requirements in place ... which would justify putting huge sums of Western money into their pockets. Their pockets have got holes in them.'' Canada was somewhere in the middle. Mulroney was anxious to find some approach to support Gorbachev. ``Where would we be if he were chucked out?'' Mulroney asked. ``If he were chucked out by some of the extreme right influences we see at play in the Soviet party conference that is ongoing in Moscow today, I think we would be at an infinitely worse position than we are today.'' And yet, Mulroney called Soviet aid to Cuba ``profoundly unacceptable'' and an obstacle to western aid. In a CBS interview, Gerasimov addressed the three main obstacles Bush has described to direct aid from the United States: Economic reform, military spending levels and subsidies to Cuba. Specifically, he said Moscow's $5 billion annual subsidy to Cuba would ``fade away, but not tomorrow,'' as the Soviets shift to market prices for sugar purchases and oil sales. Moreover, he said, ``We are now taking steps to cut our military to size. That is why they are grumbling, some of the generals.'' Canada was not ready to provide direct aid, but Mulroney said, ``Yes, we will provide credits ... We want to send out a signal that this leadership in the Soviet Union is valid and valuable.'' The $2 billion (Canadian, about $1.7 billion in U.S. funds) in credits have been granted for wheat and other products. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said Gorbachev is asking for help for a couple years as he implements his economic reforms. ``It will be a time of austerity and troubles, and what he would like is some assistance to help tide over while those economic restructuring programs are taking hold,'' Scowcroft said on CNN. He said Gorbachev was interested in ``food aid, consumer aid ... to give some hope to the average Soviet citizen that things are getting better.'' Asked if the United States would provide that help, Scowcroft said, ``It's very difficult for the United States.'' Bush would not describe Gorbachev's entreaty, explaining, ``I have some responsibilities to be sure that our summit partners are briefed on that Gorbachev letter before we go public.'' But sources said the letter was a general appeal for assistance from the West, but made no specific requests. Bush, in his adopted home state of Texas, hosted a home-style howdy for the arriving summiteers. There were cowboys and barbecue, bull riding and bucking broncs, at a Sunday night rodeo. And, the Grand Ole Opry left its hometown of Nashville to be here for a special broadcast, featuring Minnie Pearl and Loretta Lynn. Bush and Mulroney showed up for the festivities in newly made summit cowboy boots. Margaret Thatcher of Britain wore white heels. Bush treated his guests to a horseshoe throwing match and threw two ringers himself. Japan's Toshiki Kaifu tried several pitches, to no avail. The economic summit follows hard on the heels of last week's 16-nation meeting which rewrote NATO war-fighting strategy in accordance with reduced East-West tensions. The nations represented here are Britain, France, Canada, Italy, and West Germany, Japan and the United States. Britain's Hurd said the Soviet's government-controlled economy wasn't equipped to cope with massive Western assistance. The summit's message, he said, should be ``mend the hole in the pants before you fill the pockets with dimes and cents.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III _ asked about direct U.S. aid to Moscow _ said, ``No, that's not right now in the cards.'' Instead, he emphasized that the United States would continue to give technical assistance such as advice on how to move toward a market economy. West Germany and France have been pressing for a $15 billion package of Western aid for Moscow. Leaders of the European Community, meeting in Dublin last month, agreed in principle to provide assistance but stopped short of committing themselves to a specific program or amount. A formula for compromise has been suggested by Baker. He said recently the Houston summit could reach agreement on a set of guidelines and principles for assistance, short of actually sending aid. Bush removed another contentious issue from the summit agenda when he told Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu that the United States would not object to a resumption of Japanese aid to China. Japan, under pressure from Beijing as well as Japanese businesses, wants to resume at least part of the $5 billion aid package it promised to China two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Key Aspects of Louisiana's Abortion Bill
With AM-Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key elements of an abortion bill passed by the Louisiana Legislature. The bill outlaws most abortions by creating a new simple battery offense. Under the bill: _ Simple battery of abortion is the specific intent of terminating a pregnancy other than to preserve the life or health of an unborn child or to remove a dead fetus. _ Abortion on a rape victim is not a crime, providing the victim sought medical care from a licensed physician within seven days of the rape, reported the rape to law enforcement authorities within seven days of the offense and had the abortion within the first trimester of the pregnancy. _ Abortion performed in an incest pregnancy is not a crime if the abortion is performed in the first trimester. _ Only a licensed physician may perform an abortion in the circumstances allowed by law. Although simple battery in Louisiana ordinarily is a misdemeanor, with a maximum six-month prison term and $500 fine, abortionists under this bill would face prison at hard labor for one to 10 years, with fines of not less than $10,000 or more than $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Legislature Bans Abortion in Most Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to bring up discussion of legislature's procedure for passing bill, adds quote from anti-abortion legislator, CORRETS to show Roemer spokeswoman, sted spokesman made comment; picks up 13th graf, `Saunders said...
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature on Sunday passed the strictest state abortion bill, which would ban most abortions and punish doctors who perform them with up to 10 years at hard labor. The state Senate earlier had failed to override the governor's veto of an even harsher measure that would have restricted abortion even in cases of rape and incest. To pass Sunday night's measure, legislators cannibalized a failing flag burning law and outlawed abortion by creating a new crime: simple battery of abortion. The bill was hurried through the Legislature hours after the override failed. The bill passed 83-22 in the House after a 32-7 vote in the Senate. It passes now to Gov. Buddy Roemer. The bill bans abortions except in cases of rape, incest or where the mother's life is in danger. It carries a penalty of up to 10 years in prison and a $100,000 fine for doctors who perform abortions. It would not penalize the woman who seeks the abortion. Simple battery in Louisiana ordinarily is a misdemeanor, with a maximum six-month prison term and $500 fine. Pennsylvania currently has the strictest state abortion law, but it is less restrictive than the Louisiana bill. The Senate earlier had failed to override Roemer's veto of a bill that didn't allow abortion even in instances of rape and incest. So Sen. John Saunders amended anti-abortion language onto an unrelated bill. Roemer has indicated he would accept an abortion bill that contained the rape and incest exceptions. Through a spokeswoman, Roemer said he had not seen Sunday's bill and would not comment on it until Monday. Abortion rights supporters reacted with incredulity. ``We've just seen the Legislature go from the most restrictive abortion bill in the nation to the most absurd,'' said Terri Bartlett of Planned Parenthood of Louisiana. ``The only thing that surpasses it is the mockery of the legislative process.'' ``Only in Louisiana could you have a flag burning bill become an abortion bill.'' Rep. Woody Jenkins, the original bill's author, voted against the new version because of his belief ``that the unborn is a human being from the moment of conception and we ought not make exceptions to the principle. ``Even though I could not vote for the bill in the form that passed out, it is my hope and prayer that it will be used to test the continued validity of Roe vs. Wade, that it will be used to stop the senseless killing of millions of unborn children.'' Proponents of the abortion bill hope it will be challenged all the way to the Supreme Court, leading to a showdown over the 1973 high court ruling that legalized abortion. The bill Saunders chose to amend was another controversial bill _ one that would lower the penalty to a $25 fine for people who beat up flag burners. His version of the bill stripped it of the flag burning provisions and inserted the abortion issue. Saunders said his amendment was the only chance the state had of passing an anti-abortion bill. ``I don't want any more abortions than we have to have,'' he said. The Senate sustained Roemer's veto of the earlier bill Saturday with a 23-16 vote to override, three short of the needed two-thirds majority. The Pennslyvania measure, approved in November, requires a woman wait 24 hours before getting an abortion, bans abortions based on the fetus' sex and bans abortions after the 24th week of pregnancy except to save the life of the mother or prevent ``substantial and irreversible harm.'' A doctor convicted under the sex-selection ban or the 24-week provision could be punished with up to seven years in prison and a $15,000 fine. An even stricter abortion bill was passed in the U.S. territory of Guam. But it has been blocked for now by court challenges. That law makes it a felony to perform an abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. As the Senate began its work Sunday, some 1,000 demonstrators gathered on the Capitol steps and in the rotunda that separates the Senate and House chambers. A strong majority appeared to be backers of the anti-abortion bill, but there were also scores of abortion rights activists. Near the doors of the rotunda, in black spray paint, someone had scrawled the words ``Stop Killing the Innocent.'' A few feet away, abortion-rights advocates had taped a poster to the wall that read simply ``Sustain, Sustain, Sustain.'' About 300 to 400 of the anti-abortion demonstrators, some carrying Bibles and singing hymns, began a continuous march around the Capitol in the 90-degree heat. ``We're marching around the walls of Jericho,'' one shouted. At 3:30 p.m., a sudden thunderstorm came up and sent many of the demonstrators scurrying for cover. Senate President Samuel Nunez said lobbying Saturday and Sunday was intense, with thousands of telephone calls jamming switchboards. ``People were even calling the House switchboard for us becaue they couldn't get through,'' Nunez said Sunday morning. ``Our secretaries didn't keep any record of how many were for one thing and how many were for another. ``I did get a call from a woman purporting to be representing the Vatican. I talked to that woman who wanted me to change my vote. Naturally, I was suspicious and asked for her phone number. I said I would call her back. Well, she turned out to be a resident of Mandeville and works with the Friends of Americas.'' Friends of the Americas is a non-profit organization set up by Rep. Woody Jenkins, who is author of the abortion bill. The organization aids Nicaraguan refugees.

DOC.HEAD: GM-Sponsored Solar Car Rally Set for Monday
DOC.TEXT: Teams of college engineers begin a race with the sun Monday. Thirty-two college and university teams take off from Orlando, Fla., for an 11-day jaunt in solar powered cars, hoping to prove the efficiency of their designs as the auto industry looks for ways other than gasoline to power vehicles. The route covers more than 1,600 miles of secondary state and county roads in eight states, and the contestants are bound to attract some curious stares along the way. The vehicles are a long way from any assembly line. One of the chief considerations goes to wind resistance, which means that the cars hug the ground, are basically flat and have no styling excesses. ``It won't necessarily be the fastest car that wins,'' said General Motors Corp. Vice President Donald L. Runkle. ``Instead, it will be the car performing most efficiently.'' ``The team that can adapt most consistently to the daily routine will have the best chance of coming out on top,'' said Runkle, who heads the advanced engineering staff for the giant automaker, which sponsors the rally along with the federal Department of Energy and the Society of Automotive Engineers. GM and other automakers worldwide have been researching new ways to power vehicles for years. Much of the research has centered on fuels other than gasoline, including methanol, methanol-gasoline mixes, ethanol and natural gas. Late last year, GM unveiled its Impact electric car. Its performance of 0-60 mph in about eight seconds and a cruising range of about 120 miles on a single charge impressed industry observers. Strategy for the race began during the weekend at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida. The teams went through qualifying heats to determine the order of start on Monday. ``We want to make sure they are all roadworthy,'' GM spokesman Dave Sloan said Friday. Cars are entered from a variety of colleges and universities ranging from tiny Crowder College in Neosho, Mo., to the University of Texas and Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Teams from Puerto Rico and Canada also are entered. Each team received $5,000 from GM and $2,000 from the Energy Department along with whatever funds could be raised through the school, local and state governments or elsewhere. That's only part of the investment. For instance, about $750,000 has been spent on the car from the University of Michigan. Vehicles will start each day at 30 second intervals, with the previous day's winner going first. Average speeds are expected to be in the 30 mph range. Crews will be allowed to charge batteries for two hours before and after each day's racing. The winner will be the team with the least total elapsed time. The course passes through Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio and Indiana before winding up at the GM Technical Center in Warren, Mich., north of Detroit, on the afternoon of July 19. The top three finishers will be sponsored by GM in worldwide solar car competition later this year in Australia. GM's Sunraycer solar vehicle won the first worldwide solar car race in 1987. The Sunraycer is on display in the Smithsonian Institution.

DOC.HEAD: Accountants Dog S&L Crooks, Hunt For Doctored Books
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to restore dropped first reference to Sibley.
DOC.TEXT: Robbers do not need guns _ pencil and paper will do. So say two accountants who have built a business of finding financial fraud. ``Put enough zeroes behind a number, and it's amazing how flexible morals become,'' said James A. Smith, a partner of Smith, Sibley & Co. accountants. The firm, which specializes in the practice known as forensic accounting, is one of many hired by the federal government to help clean up the savings and loan industry. Smith and his partner, Kenneth Sibley, use traditional accounting methods, tallying assets and estimating losses, to detect the value of S&L property and uncover fraud. ``It is ... very laborious, number-crunching ... meticulous attention to detail,'' Smith said. But they've had some anxious moments during a few audits. Once a distraught executive was told the home office had ordered him to hand over his books to Smith & Sibley. He began pacing around the office with a baseball bat. He never swung the bat, Sibley said, but it was close. Smith was introduced to forensic accounting via the Watergate scandal. He helped unravel a slush fund through which Braniff Airlines Inc. funneled money to pay bribes to gain South American landing rights. Accountants discovered Braniff used the same fund for an illegal contribution to Richard Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign. Over the years, forensic accounting has grown to about 15 percent of the firm's work. Sibley is one of 3,000 members of the National Association of Certified Fraud Examiners. As part of a team working under contract with the Resolution Trust Corp., Smith and Sibley now help determine the value of assets held by insolvent thrifts that are under government conservatorship. The partners have seen their forensic speciality take on more importance as companies, especially small ones, realize their profits are being stolen and call on the accountants for help. Fraud occurs in many small businesses because their owners do not take care to protect their assets. ``They do not mind the store,'' said Sibley. He likes to tell of the doctor who turned over all his bill-paying to a nurse who used his charge account number to buy things for herself. The doctor never bothered to look at the bills and only discovered he was being robbed when his accountant asked why his interest payments were so high. But small businesses are not the only victims. Smith and Sibley related the twisted tale of one crook: A teller at a Dallas bank was convicted of making false entries on the books of a savings and loan and sentenced to prison. Two months out of jail, he was working for a construction company as a controller. He would make out false invoices to fictitious vendors. After the owner of the company signed the checks, the thief would blot out the fictitious vendor's name, substitute his own and deposit them into his own account via night deposit. The checks were always paid despite the obvious altering, and $600,000 was stolen before the crime was discovered, Sibley said. It was too late to save the business; the losses broke the company. The thief fled Texas, but turned up later in the offices of an international accounting firm. ``He was again convicted and sent to the Wynne Prison in Huntsville, where he wound up participating in the prison farm accounting office,'' according to Smith & Sibley's history of the case. ``Not surprisingly, a huge shortage was found in the prison accounting office.'' Convictions are unusual, Sibley said, because many businesses want only to recoup their losses and won't go to court. Such reluctance, he believes, has led to increased white collar crime, although Sibley said he senses attitudes are changing. ``Management is more and more realizing that they have to send people to jail,'' he said. He believes the attention given to multibillion-dollar savings and loan scandals has spurred law enforcement agencies' interest in white collar crime. ``In the past, it has not been publicized,'' Sibley said, and ``the lack of prosecution makes it more attractive.'' Sibley hesitated when asked for specifics about his firm's methods of tracking money. He preferred to talk in generalities about access to sales receipts, bank records and numerous other sources. ``Documentation, or in some instances lack of documentation, builds the case,'' Sibley said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Wine Sales Down 5 percent 2nd Straight Year
DOC.TEXT: Wine consumption in the U.S. dropped sharply for the second straight year in 1989, with Mississippians drinking the least and tipplers in the District of Columbia the most, a trade publication reported. Drinkers in California, New York and Washington, the top three wine-producing states, drank the most wine per capita, but New Hampshire was the only state to show a gain in consumption over 1988, according to Wines & Vines. Americans last year drank 2.11 gallons of wine per capita, the lowest consumption of any major wine-producing nation and a 5.8 percent drop from 1988. Consumption in 1988 dropped 5 percent from 1987 figures. By comparison, Americans over 21 drank 33.7 gallons of beer, 2.16 gallons of distilled spirits, and about 35 gallons of coffee. Adult-only wine consumption was 3.03 gallons per capita. Reflecting a national trend against alcohol consumption, individual states posted figures showing as much as a 19.5 percent drop from 1988. That distinction went to Arizona, where a half-gallon less of wine per capita was consumed last year than in 1988. The domestic wine market, including imports, fell 5.2 percent to 523 million gallons. It was a 64.1 million gallon drop from a high point of 587.1 million gallons in 1986, the report said. Domestic table wines fell 2.6 percent while production of domestic champagnes dropped 6.3 percent. Last year marked the fourth straight year of decline for foreign champagne sales in this country; they were down 7.8 percent to 12 million gallons. In 1985, champagne imports to the United States hit a peak of 15.8 million gallons, almost all of it from Italy, France and Spain. California wines accounted for 72.8 percent of all wine consumed in the U.S. last year, while the other 42 wine-producing states held 12.6 percent of the market. The rest of the market, 14.6 percent, were imports. Wines & Vines blamed the market drop on the continuing loss of ground of generic or jug wines, nearly all of it produced in California's San Joaquin Valley, and a 16.7 percent dip in wine cooler sales. It was the second double-digit loss in two years for the coolers, sales phenomenon of the early 1980s that literally rescued California wine for several years. In 1988 and 1989, cooler sales fell 33.3 million gallons, falling from 21 percent of wine market share to 17 percent last year. Still, the coolers _ mostly cheap white wine, fruit juice and carbonated water _ represented one of six gallons of wine sold in this country last year. There were at least three bright spots for the industry, including a relatively weak U.S. dollar and its built-in price advantage over imports. Blush varietals such as white zinfandel and white grenache, prime fuels for the top selling white wine segment, continued to gain market share, while the booming premiums, which cost over $3 a standard bottle, increased 7 percent, at a slower rate than previous postings. U.S. wine exports were up again in 1989, showing foreign sales increased to a miniscule 22.1 million gallons in 1989 from 16.9 gallons in 1988. The top two markets are Canada, 5.7 million gallons, and Japan, 5.5 million gallons.

DOC.HEAD: Canada, U.S. To Begin Air Pollution Talks This Month
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Sunday their nations would begin negotiations on an air pollution agreement this month. The announcement was foreseen a year ago when Bush decided to seek new controls on the sources of acid rain, an issue Canada has been complaining about for a decade. Both houses of Congress have passed different versions of legislation requiring utility smokestacks to reduce extensively emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, the principal raw materials causing acid rain. Environmentalists monitoring the economic summit welcomed the announcement and said it was inevitable. In a session before the summit officially begins Monday, Bush and Mulroney set an informal timetable for talks to begin on an air pollution agreement. William Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will meet with his counterpart, Robert de Cotret, in Ottawa, Canada, on July 16, the leaders said. Formal negotiations should begin shortly after that, they said. ``I think this day will be long remembered in the history of our relationship for the significant departure it constitutes from past positions,'' Mulroney said. He and other Canadian leaders have been rebuffed in the past in their attempt to prod the United States into curbing pollutants. A White House announcement said the talks with Canada would cover monitoring of emissions, exchange of information and settlement of disputes. Scientists on both sides of the border agree about half the acid rain falling in eastern Canada originates from emissions generated by utilities and smokestacks in the United States. Because of wind patterns, about a quarter of the acid rain falling in the Adirondack Mountains of New York States originates in Canada. Former President Reagan argued that not enough was known to conclude that acid rain was a serious problem; Canada said marine life in as many as 14,000 lakes is in jeopardy. Environmentalists, meanwhile, denounced what they said was the failure of the seven summit nations to live up to the rhetoric of last year's meeting in Paris in which they pledged to protect the world's environment. The leaders agreed in 1989 to end production of chemicals that destroy the earth's protective ozone layer, said George T. Frampton, president of The Wilderness Society. ``The reality is that our forests are being cut just as fast as they were a year ago, Frampton said. ``Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are being emitted into the atmosphere at just the same high volume, or even greater, than that of a year ago. Population growth and ocean pollution have continued unabated.'' An environmental coalition of 150 groups is keeping a scorecard designed to hold governments accountable by publicizing their records, Frampton said. The environmentalists have already ranked the countries attending the summit. West Germany was rated top, followed by France, Britain, Canada, the United States, Japan and Italy. The countries were ranked based on their policies on conserving energy and reducing the threat of global warming; protecting biological diversity such as that found in tropical forests, abating pollution of the oceans, controlling population growth, helping the cleanup of Eastern Europe and helping develoing nations. Germany's high score was ``the best of a bad lot,'' said Jay Hair, executive vice president of the National Wildlife Federation.
